Ryanair Cuts October Capacity by Another 20%; Blames Lower Bookings on 'Continuous Changes' in EU 
Travel Restrictions
Ryanair Cuts October Capacity by Another 20%; Blames Lower Bookings on 
'Continuous Changes' in EU Travel Restrictions
MT Newswires Live Briefs
September 18, 2020 Friday 8:44 AM EST
Copyright 2020 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 185 words
Body
 Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY) reported that it would lower its October capacity by another 20% on top of the 20% 
reduction already announced by the company in August. 
The Irish airline operator said it now expects its October capacity to fall from 50% to approximately 40% of its 
October 2019 levels, but expects to maintain a load factor of at least 70% at the reduced schedule.
The airline blamed the capacity reductions on continuous changes in EU government travel restrictions and 
policies, many of which it said have been introduced at short notice, which undermine consumers' willingness to 
make forward bookings.
"As customer confidence is damaged by government mismanagement of Covid travel policies, many Ryanair 
customers are unable to travel for business or urgent family reasons without being subjected to defective 14 day 
quarantines," a Ryanair spokesperson said. "If current trends and EU governments' mismanagement of the return 
of air travel and normal economic activity continue, then similar capacity cuts may be required across the winter 
period."
Price: 83.71, Change: -3.98, Percent Change: -4.54
Load-Date: September 18, 2020
End of Document
Ryanair Gets Majority Shareholder Support For CEO's FY20 Payout
Ryanair Gets Majority Shareholder Support For CEO's FY20 Payout
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
September 18, 2020 Friday 1:33 AM EST
Copyright 2020 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 81 words
Body
 About 65.8% of Ryanair's (RYA.L) shareholders approved CEO Michael O'Leary's fiscal 2020 bonus of 458,000 
euros ($542,696), according to a company statement on Thursday.
However, a number of investors including proxy adviser Institutional Shareholder Services criticized the payout 
amid the economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the travel sector.
The airline's shares increased about 1% at the close of market on Thursday.
Price (GBP): £12.57, Change: £0.13, Percent Change: +1.05%

Italy 's ENAC, Ryanair Discuss Compliance With Health Protocols Amid COVID-19
Italy's ENAC, Ryanair Discuss Compliance With Health Protocols Amid 
COVID-19
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
September 18, 2020 Friday 1:12 AM EST
Copyright 2020 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 109 words
Body
 Italy's national civil aviation authority ENAC met with representatives from Ryanair Holdings (RYA.L), which was 
accused of not complying with COVID-19 health and safety protocols, Reuters reported Thursday, citing an ENAC 
statement.
ENAC said it "reminded Ryanair of the requirement for the carrier to ensure that measures laid down in Italy to limit 
the health risks from coronavirus are respected."
However, Ryanair Chief Executive Michael O'Leary denied reports of any noncompliance of health regulations by 
the carrier, according to Irish state broadcaster RTE.
Ryanair closed over 1% on Thursday.
Price (GBP): £12.57, Change: £0.13, Percent Change: +1.05%

Ryanair Cuts October Capacity By 20% As COVID-19 Travel Policies Hurt Forward Bookings
Ryanair Cuts October Capacity By 20% As COVID-19 Travel Policies Hurt 
Forward Bookings
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
September 18, 2020 Friday 5:44 AM EST
Copyright 2020 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 96 words
Body
 Ryanair Holdings (RYA.L) said Friday it reduced its capacity for October by an additional 20% due to a decline in 
forward bookings following "continuous changes" in COVID-19 travel restrictions by European governments.
Consequently, October capacity will plunge to 40% from October 2019 levels.
The airline added that a number of customers are apprehensive to travel due to the "government mismanagement 
of COVID travel policies" and the mandatory 14-day quarantine rule.
The company's shares tumbled 4% on Friday morning.
Price (GBP): £12.07, Change: £-0.49, Percent Change: -3.94%
Load-Date: September 18, 2020

unusual hurricane-like storm has reached Greece, flooding western islands and disrupting aviation. Coastguards 
say a boat carrying 55 migrants is adrift in the poor conditions.Storm Ianos, classed by forecasters as a rare 
hurricane-like "medicane," downed trees and caused flooding and power outages on Greece's Ionian islands on 
Friday, packing winds of up to 117 kilometers (73 miles) per hour.Coastguards said a boat carrying some 55 
migrants was in distress off the Peloponnese peninsula, southwest of Athens, and urged vessels in the area to 
assist.National weather researcher Kostas Lagouvardos on state ERT television cautioned: "We have another 36 
hours of intense conditions ahead of us."Deputy Civil Protection Minister Nikos Hardalias said Ianos was likely to 
"remain west" and then head south, but could still bring heavy rain to the Athens region on Saturday.Read more:

protection agency urged residents on the islands of Zakynthos, Cephalonia, and Ithaki, as well as other areas in the 
west to refrain from non-essential travel and to avoid basements."Trees are falling everywhere," Ionian Islands 
governor Rodi Kratsa told ERT on Friday and the state news agency ANA said a Swiss sailing boat moored off 
Ithaki was shoved to sea by waves. 
Its two occupants managed to make it back to shore, ANA added.Aviation was disrupted with two Ryanair flights 
unable to land on the island of Cephalonia. They were rerouted to Athens.Read more: Germany to take in some

from three camps near Athens, would be relocated to a conference hall.A further 28 minors from a fourth camp 
would be temporarily taken to a hotel.Mediterranean tropical-like cyclones, or medicanes, have become more 
frequent over the past 25 years, including one in 2017 where flash flooding killed 25 people.ipj/msh (AFP, dpa, AP,

Ryanair to cut capacity by 20 per cent, blames pandemic travel rules
Ryanair to cut capacity by 20 per cent, blames pandemic travel rules
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 18, 2020 Friday 1:16 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 188 words
Dateline: Dublin (dpa) - 
Body
Ryanair said on Friday that it will slash capacity by 20 per cent in October, blaming coronavirus travel curbs 
introduced at short notice.
Dublin-based Ryanair, Europe's biggest airline, said "EU government travel restrictions and policies" aimed at 
stopping the spread of the novel coronavirus "undermine consumers' willingness to make forward bookings."
Announcing its second 20 per cent capacity reduction since August, Ryanair accused the Irish government of 
keeping the country "locked up like North Korea" and of operating "a defective" quarantine system that 
means arrivals from most countries, some with lower infection rates than Ireland, are expected to self-isolate for 14 
days.
Supported by Aer Lingus, Ireland's flag carrier airline, Ryanair has taken the government to court over the curbs, 
which will not be aligned with EU guidelines until mid-October.
On Wednesday, lawyers representing the government told Ireland's High Court that the measures are not 
mandatory.
The government on Thursday cut Italy and Greece from its "green list" of countries from where arrivals are not 
expected to self-isolate but added Germany.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Mark Meadows  Tel: +49 30 2852 31472; <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: September 18, 2020

consensus rating of Buy and an average price target of $79.00.Shares of RYAAY[2] opened at $87.69 on Monday.

day moving average price is $80.68 and its 200-day moving average price is $68.09. Ryanair has a 52 week low of

of 1.39. Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last issued its quarterly earnings results on Monday, July 27th. The 
transportation company reported ($0.94) EPS for the quarter, topping analysts' consensus estimates of ($1.15) by 
$0.21. Ryanair had a return on equity of 10.45% and a net margin of 3.61%. The firm had revenue of $137.83 
million for the quarter, compared to analysts' expectations of $138.60 million. On average, equities analysts 
anticipate that Ryanair will post -4.3 EPS for the current year. Institutional investors have recently modified their

Ryanair investors back O'Leary bonus, but a third withhold support
Ryanair investors back O'Leary bonus, but a third withhold support
Business World (Digest)
September 17, 2020 Thursday
Copyright 2020 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: GENERAL; Ireland
Length: 300 words
Byline: Business World
Body
Ryanair shareholders backed a €458,000 bonus for Group CEO Michael O'Leary on Thursday, although more than 
a third withheld their support following criticism of the payout at a time of industry crisis.
Shareholders approved the Irish budget carrier's remuneration report, which included the award, with 65.8% in 
favor, the company said in a statement.
Proxy advisor Institutional Shareholder Services (ISS) had said the pay award for the financial year ended in March 
"raises concerns" and was hard to justify amid the unprecedented aviation crisis sparked by COVID-19.
O'Leary's base salary and maximum bonus for the year to the end of March 2020 were each cut by 50% to 500,000 
euros, according to the company's annual report.
Speaking to Reuters in an interview last week ahead of the annual general meeting (AGM), O'Leary said those cuts 
"by any measure would be indicative of the board responding appropriately to the pandemic."
"I'd like to see what the chief executive of ISS, what his pay was reduced by over the past 12 months. It'll certainly 
be less than mine," O'Leary added.
A spokeswoman for ISS said it did not disclose executive pay as it was a private company. "We don't make such 
disclosures," she said.
O'Leary's pay has proved contentious before. His five-year bonus plan, worth up to €100 million if targets related to 
share price and profitability are hit, scraped through with 50.5% support in a shareholder vote last September.
Ryanair investors back O'Leary bonus, but a third withhold support
ISS also recommended shareholders in Ryanair rival IAG, which owns British Airways and Aer Lingus, reject a 
payment of &pound;883,000 pounds to departing chief executive Willie Walsh. That payment that was approved by 
shareholders last week.
Ryanair did not provide any media access to its AGM, citing COVID-19 restrictions. (Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: October 7, 2020
End of Document
Italy and Greece taken off green list
Italy and Greece taken off green list
Business World (Digest)
September 17, 2020 Thursday
Copyright 2020 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: IRELAND
Length: 313 words
Byline: Business World
Body
The government today tightened its COVID-19 travel restrictions by imposing quarantines on travellers from major 
holiday markets Italy and Greece, angering the country's dominant airlines Ryanair and Aer Lingus.
Aer Lingus said it was concerned by the fact the government had repeatedly indicated in recent weeks it planned to 
adopt a more liberal European Commission proposal, but instead cut back the number of countries exempt from 
quarantine.
Ireland had initially waived quarantine for travellers from countries with lower COVID-19 rates, but as its 14-day 
infection rate surged to above 50 cases per 100,000, the government said only places half that rate would be 
exempt.
The move came as the head of Ireland's COVID-19 modelling group on Wednesday warned of "exponential growth" 
without new restrictions.
The new "Green List", which goes into effect on Monday, allows travellers arriving from just seven countries to 
avoid quarantine: Cyprus, Finland, Germany, Iceland, Latvia, Lithuania and Poland.
The Commission envisages the removal of travel restrictions on countries with 14-day infection rates of under 50 
per 100,000. The Taoiseach has promised to implement the EU rules once they are officially approved on Oct. 13.
"The 'green list' announced today does not represent a step towards alignment with the European Commission’s 
free movement proposal," Aer Lingus said in a statement.
Italy and Greece taken off green list
Ryanair, which is taking a case to the Irish High Court challenging the legality of the quarantine rules, said the 
aviation and tourism sectors "cannot afford any further delays or indecision."
The airline has threatened to close bases in the country's second and third largest airports, Shannon and Cork, for 
the winter unless restrictions are eased.
On Thursday Group Chief Executive Michael O'Leary said capacity at Dublin airport may also be cut. (Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: October 7, 2020
End of Document
Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Short Interest Up 12.9% in August
Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Short Interest Up 12.9% in August
American Banking and Market News
September 17, 2020 Thursday
Copyright 2020 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 718 words
Body
Ryanair logo Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) saw a large growth in short interest during the month of 
August. As of August 31st, there was short interest totalling 1,580,000 shares,  a growth of 12.9% from the August 
15th total of 1,400,000 shares. Based on an average daily trading volume, of 520,300 shares, the short-interest 
ratio is currently 3.0 days.  
•
Airline Stocks - Top Airline Stocks to Buy Now 
Shares of NASDAQ:RYAAY  opened at $87.49 on Thursday. The business's 50 day simple moving average is 
$80.47 and its 200-day simple moving average is $68.01. The firm has a market capitalization of $19.69 billion, a 
price-to-earnings ratio of 77.42 and a beta of 1.39. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.60, a current ratio of 
0.67 and a quick ratio of 0.67. Ryanair has a 12 month low of $44.44 and a 12 month high of $96.79.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last announced its quarterly earnings results on Monday, July 27th. The transportation 
company reported ($0.94) EPS for the quarter, topping the Thomson Reuters' consensus estimate of ($1.15) by 
$0.21. The business had revenue of $137.83 million for the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of $138.60 
million. Ryanair had a return on equity of 10.45% and a net margin of 3.61%.  On average, equities analysts 
anticipate that  Ryanair will post -4.3 earnings per share for the current year.  
Several large investors have recently made changes to their positions in RYAAY. Mitsubishi UFJ Trust & Banking 
Corp lifted its stake in shares of  Ryanair by 0.4% during the second quarter. Mitsubishi UFJ Trust & Banking Corp

a buy rating to the company's stock. The stock  has a consensus rating of "Buy" and an average price target of 
$79.00. 
About Ryanair
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) Short Interest Up 12.9% in August
Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Short Interest Up 12.9% in August
American Banking and Market News
September 17, 2020 Thursday
Copyright 2020 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 654 words
Body
Ryanair logo Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) saw a large growth in short interest during the month of 
August. As of August 31st, there was short interest totalling 1,580,000 shares,  a growth of 12.9% from the August 
15th total of 1,400,000 shares. Based on an average daily trading volume, of 520,300 shares, the short-interest 
ratio is currently 3.0 days.  
Shares of NASDAQ:RYAAY  opened at $87.49 on Thursday. The business's 50 day simple moving average is 
$80.47 and its 200-day simple moving average is $68.01. The firm has a market capitalization of $19.69 billion, a 
price-to-earnings ratio of 77.42 and a beta of 1.39. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.60, a current ratio of 
0.67 and a quick ratio of 0.67. Ryanair has a 12 month low of $44.44 and a 12 month high of $96.79.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last announced its quarterly earnings results on Monday, July 27th. The transportation 
company reported ($0.94) EPS for the quarter, topping the Thomson Reuters' consensus estimate of ($1.15) by 
$0.21. The business had revenue of $137.83 million for the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of $138.60 
million. Ryanair had a return on equity of 10.45% and a net margin of 3.61%.  On average, equities analysts 
anticipate that  Ryanair will post -4.3 earnings per share for the current year.  
Several large investors have recently made changes to their positions in RYAAY. Mitsubishi UFJ Trust & Banking 
Corp lifted its stake in shares of  Ryanair by 0.4% during the second quarter. Mitsubishi UFJ Trust & Banking Corp 
now owns 549,818 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $36,475,000 after buying an additional 
2,402 shares during the period.  Brave Warrior Advisors LLC acquired a new position in  Ryanair in the 2nd quarter 
valued at $16,486,000.  Covenant Partners LLC raised its holdings in  Ryanair by 19.7% in the 2nd quarter. 
Covenant Partners LLC now owns 11,298 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $750,000 after 
acquiring an additional 1,860 shares during the last quarter.  Private Advisor Group LLC acquired a new position in  
Ryanair in the 2nd quarter valued at $25,000.  Finally, U S Global Investors Inc. raised its holdings in  Ryanair by 
186.9% in the 2nd quarter. U S Global Investors Inc. now owns 171,920 shares of the transportation company's 
stock valued at $11,406,000 after acquiring an additional 112,004 shares during the last quarter. 44.15% of the 
stock is currently owned by institutional investors and hedge funds.  
A number of brokerages have issued reports on RYAAY. BidaskClub downgraded Ryanair from a "buy" rating to a 
"hold" rating in a report on Friday, August 21st. UBS Group  reiterated a "buy" rating on shares of Ryanair in a 
research report on Wednesday, May 20th. Raymond James cut Ryanair from a "strong-buy" rating to an 
"outperform" rating and set a $90.00 target price on the stock. in a research report on Friday, September 4th.

Will France 's 150 airports survive?
Will France's 150 airports survive?
Airguide Business & AirguideBusiness.com
September 17, 2020
Copyright 2020 Pyramid Media Group Inc. All Rights Reserved
Section: Air and Travel Business Features; ISSN: 1939-666X
Length: 691 words
Body
The French government has allocated (EURO)15billion to sustain the sector, which the International Air Transport 
Association says is facing 466,100 job losses in France alone. The industry must also confront environmental 
challenges, including a move to greener energy with solar, electric and hybrid planes.
Despite all this, award-winning French aviation journalist Gil Roy argues there is still plenty of life in France's 
airports - great and small.
French airports affected by Covid-19
Fears that the small regional airports that provided easy pre-Covid links with the UK might be in danger will 
probably not materialise. There are around 150 airports in the French airports trade body - one of the highest 
numbers among EU countries - and even before the pandemic there were occasional calls for a rationalisation of 
the network.
Last year, for example, some councillors in Normandy said having three council-funded airports - Le Havre, 
Deauville and Caen - within 30km of each other was too expensive. Author and journalist Gil Roy, who runs the 
Aerobuzz.fr website and who was awarded France's Médaille de l'Aéronautique for his contribution to spreading 
knowledge about aeronautics in France, said his opinion is that all airports will remain open.
"They are owned by towns and other local government bodies, and people are very, very proud of them," he said. 
"Even when it involves a big financial sacrifice, people will do all they can to keep airports open, as a matter of local 
pride, and also because of the tangible economic and other benefits that they bring."
The problem is more likely to come, he warned, from the airlines, especially low-cost providers such as Ryanair and 
Easyjet that serve smaller regional airports.
Futures unclear
"The airports are prepared to pay to continue the services they have, but it is not clear whether the airlines will 
return to the routes they had in the past," he said. An example of how local authorities are determined to keep their 
airports is Angoulême, which lengthened its runway to attract Ryanair - and then lost the service after a short time 
in a legal row over how much the owners of the airport should pay the airline to land there.
Will France 's 150 airports survive?
For a while, it had regular flights linking Angoulême with Corsica during the holiday season and a regular "air taxi" 
linking the city with Lyon, but they also stopped. Since then, the airport has remained open, with a helicopter 
training school and aircraft maintenance companies providing its only revenue. A flying club also uses the facilities.
Mr Roy said the legal disputes at Angoulême had served as a wake-up call to other airports. "Since then, they have 
been very clear that the agreements they sign with airlines and others meet all the government's rules and all 
Europe's rules," he said. "It is unlikely that even if the Cour des Comptes [France's official controlling body of state 
expenditure] opened an investigation, it would be able to fault the airports."
What are Air France's plans?
Air France has published a list of airports it hopes to be able to use by this month, linking the provinces with Paris 
Charles de Gaulle. The airports are: Biarritz, Bordeaux, Brest, Clermont Ferrand, Lorient, Lyon, Marseille, 
Montpellier, Mulhouse, Nantes, Nice, Pau, Rennes, and Toulouse.
In addition, services to Aurillac, Brive, Castres and Lourdes, where the airline holds a Délégation de Service Public 
grant to provide links to Paris, are due to start later. Bordeaux is included on the list, even though the airline was 
told to stop flying routes where TGV trains made the same journey in under 2h30 minutes. Air France got an 
exception for flights to Charles de Gaulle because the airport is a hub for international travel. Air France flights 
between Orly airport in Paris and Bordeaux have been scrapped.

Lufthansa ramps up Frankfurt's short-haul leisure offer
Lufthansa ramps up Frankfurt's short-haul leisure offer
Airguide Business & AirguideBusiness.com
September 17, 2020
Copyright 2020 Pyramid Media Group Inc. All Rights Reserved
Section: Air and Travel Business News and Features; ISSN: 1939-666X
Length: 547 words
Body
Fifteen vacation destinations are being added to Lufthansa's network from Frankfurt for the summer 2021 season.
Lufthansa said it is responding to passenger demand by increasing the number of leisure routes offered from its 
Frankfurt (FRA) hub.
Fifteen short-haul destinations are being added to the Star Alliance member's network for the summer 2021 
season. Greece and Spain are a key focus-collectively accounting for nine of the 15 new services-but flights are 
also being added to Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Egypt, Italy and Tunisia.
"Never before have we included so many new vacation destinations in our program," Lufthansa executive Harry 
Hohmeister said.
"This is our response to the wishes of our customers. The demand for vacation and leisure trips is recovering much 
faster than that for business trips."
By deploying up to five additional aircraft, Lufthansa plans to offer around 70 weekly connections to 29 tourist 
destinations from FRA, 15 more than in the same period last year.
The airline said the new routes would depart the German airport in the morning and arrive in the evening in order to 
maximize time at the destinations for passengers.
The southern European airports being added to Lufthansa's FRA network are Chania (CHQ), Corfu (CFU), 
Djerba (DJE), Hurghada (HRG), Jerez de la Frontera (XRY), Kavala (KVA), Kos (KGS), Lamezia Terme (SUF), 
Mykonos (JMK), Paphos (PFO), Preveza (PVK), Rijeka (RJK) and Varna (VAR). Winter service to Gran Canaria 
(LPA) and Tenerife South (TFS) will also be maintained in summer 2021.
As reported by Airlineroute, two of the 15 routes are resumptions. Lufthansa previously served Djerba, an island off 
the coast of Tunisia, until October 1983. The carrier also operated flights to Jerez de la Frontera (pictured), a city in 
Spain's Andalusia region, in July and August 2013.
The leisure additions to Lufthansa's network from FRA come as subsidiary Eurowings confirmed plans to add a 
slew of vacation destinations in Greece, Portugal and Spain from Dusseldorf (DUS).
Lufthansa ramps up Frankfurt's short-haul leisure offer
The low-cost unit is taking advantage of Ryanair's base closure at DUS by taking over up to 95% of the routes that 
have been operated by the Irish carrier.
The extended flying program includes services to Spanish vacation destinations Alicante (ALC), Fuerteventura 
(FUE), Ibiza (IBZ), LPA, Malaga (AGP), Palma de Mallorca (PMI) and TFS; Corfu (CFU), Heraklion (HER), KGS 
and Rhodes (RHO) in Greece; and Faro (FAO) in Portugal.
Earlier this week, Lufthansa CEO Carsten Spohr reported passenger traffic levels are currently less than 20% of 
2019 levels, but he expressed hope that demand would be at minus 25% by the end of the year. That is still around 
half of a projection he gave earlier in the pandemic.
OAG Schedules Analyser data shows Lufthansa is this week (w/c Sept. 14) offering about 507,000 departure seats 
across 3,500 flights. This compares with 1.9 million seats and 11,200 flights during the same week a year ago.

OAG Schedules Analyser data shows Lufthansa is this week (w/c Sept. 14) offering about 507,000 departure seats

Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) Given Consensus Recommendation of 'Buy' by Analysts
Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Given Consensus Recommendation 
of 'Buy' by Analysts
Newstex Blogs 
Watchlist News

Sep 16, 2020( Watchlist News: http://www.watchlistnews.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  Ryanair Holdings plc 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY) Given Consensus Recommendation of 'Buy' by Analysts September 16th, 2020 - Comments 
Off on Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Given Consensus Recommendation of 'Buy' by Analysts - Filed 
Under[1] - by Mark Dietrich[2]   Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) has been assigned an average rating of 
'Buy' from the twenty-one analysts that are covering the company, MarketBeat Ratings[3] reports. One investment 
analyst has rated the stock with a sell recommendation, six have assigned a hold recommendation and thirteen 
have issued a buy recommendation on the company. The average 1 year price objective among analysts that have 
issued ratings on the stock in the last year is $79.00.  Several research firms recently weighed in on RYAAY. 
Credit Suisse Group reiterated an 'outperform' rating on shares of Ryanair in a report on Tuesday, July 28th. 
Barclays reiterated an 'overweight' rating on shares of Ryanair in a report on Friday, August 14th. Liberum Capital 
downgraded shares of Ryanair from a 'buy' rating to a 'hold' rating in a report on Monday. Zacks Investment 
Research[4] upgraded shares of Ryanair from a 'strong sell' rating to a 'buy' rating and set a $68.00 target price for 
the company in a report on Tuesday, May 26th. Finally, Raymond James downgraded shares of Ryanair from a 
'strong-buy' rating to an 'outperform' rating and set a $90.00 price target for the company. in a research note on 
Friday, September 4th. A number of institutional investors and hedge funds have recently made changes to their 
positions in RYAAY. Private Advisor Group LLC purchased a new stake in Ryanair in the second quarter valued at 
$25,000. Rockefeller Capital Management L.P. lifted its position in Ryanair by 239.7% in the second quarter. 
Rockefeller Capital Management L.P. now owns 822 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at 
$55,000 after acquiring an additional 580 shares during the last quarter. PNC Financial Services Group Inc. lifted its 
position in Ryanair by 23.5% in the second quarter. PNC Financial Services Group Inc. now owns 958 shares of the 
transportation company's stock valued at $64,000 after acquiring an additional 182 shares during the last quarter. 
Harbor Investment Advisory LLC purchased a new stake in shares of Ryanair in the first quarter valued at about 
$91,000. Finally, Tower Research Capital LLC TRC purchased a new stake in shares of Ryanair in the first quarter 
valued at about $124,000. 44.15% of the stock is owned by hedge funds and other institutional investors.   RYAAY 
stock[5] opened at $85.83 on Wednesday. The firm has a market cap of $19.32 billion, a PE ratio of 75.96 and a 
beta of 1.39. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.60, a quick ratio of 0.67 and a current ratio of 0.67. The 
firm's 50 day moving average price is $80.21 and its 200-day moving average price is $67.96. Ryanair has a one 
year low of $44.44 and a one year high of $96.79. Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last released its quarterly earnings 
results on Monday, July 27th. The transportation company reported ($0.94) EPS for the quarter, beating the 
Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) Given Consensus Recommendation of 'Buy' by Analysts
Thomson Reuters' consensus estimate of ($1.15) by $0.21. The firm had revenue of $137.83 million for the quarter, 
compared to analyst estimates of $138.60 million. Ryanair had a net margin of 3.61% and a return on equity of 
10.45%. Equities research analysts predict that Ryanair will post -4.3 EPS for the current fiscal year.  Ryanair 
Company Profile Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services 
in Ireland, the United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of 
various ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of 
beverages, food, and merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel 
insurance through its Website. Featured Article: Why do companies issue stock splits?[6] Receive News &#38;

and analysts' ratings for Ryanair and related companies with MarketBeat.com's FREE daily email newsletter[7].

Eurowings takes over majority of Ryanair routes from Düsseldorf
Eurowings takes over majority of Ryanair routes from Düsseldorf
Airguide Business & AirguideBusiness.com
September 16, 2020
Copyright 2020 Pyramid Media Group Inc. All Rights Reserved
Section: Air and Travel Business News and Features; ISSN: 1939-666X
Length: 386 words
Body
Lufthansa's LCC steps in to offer flights from DUS to the vacation destinations in Greece, Portugal and Spain.
Lufthansa LCC subsidiary Eurowings is taking advantage of Ryanair's base closure at Düsseldorf International 
Airport (DUS) in Germany as it plans to take over up to 95% of the routes that have been operated by the Irish 
carrier.
The increased flight program should start on Oct. 24, the day when Ryanair wet-lease operator Laudamotion closes 
its base at DUS, which will see the loss of 150 crew jobs and seven Airbus A320 from the airport. Laudamotion co-
CEO Andreas Gruber previously told Aviation Week Network that the decision to close the DUS base was made by 
parent Ryanair, which is also closing its base at Stuttgart Airport (STR) on Sept. 30 affecting 70 jobs.
Eurowings CEO Jens Bischof said in a Sept. 15 statement that the closure of the Ryanair bases in Stuttgart and 
Düsseldorf was just the beginning. "With a closer look, the ultra-low-cost business model all over Germany is on its 
way to shrinking... Our clients don't search for tickets of (EURO)5 in times of a crisis, they are demanding an airline 
in which they can trust."
The number of Eurowings destinations from Düsseldorf-where the airline is headquartered-increases now to more 
than 80. The extended flying program includes services to Spanish vacation destinations Alicante (ALC), 
Fuerteventura (FUE), Gran Canaria (LPA), Ibiza (IBZ), Malaga (AGP), Palma de Mallorca (PMI) and Tenerife (TFS); 
Corfu (CFU), Heraklion (HER), Kos (KGS) and Rhodes (RHO) in Greece; and Faro (FAO) in Portugal.
Aviation Week Network understands that Eurowings has enough capacity available to handle the additional flight 
offering.
On Sept. 2 Eurowings said it would fly around 50 aircraft this autumn, but that will now likely be fewer as demand 
has weakened. From its current 90-strong fleet, the Lufthansa subsidiary has around 40 aircraft in long-term 
storage. "We have too many aircraft," Bischof said Sept. 2.
AirGuide and Pyramid Media connects you to an affluent, influential group of business and leisure travelers from 
across

globe

Eurowings takes over majority of Ryanair routes from Düsseldorf
Load-Date: December 29, 2020

Bank of America Corp DE Sells 61,004 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY)
Bank of America Corp DE Sells 61,004 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY)
Newstex Blogs 
Watchlist News
September 16, 2020 Wednesday 12:30 PM EST
Copyright 2020 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 1040 words
Body
Sep 16, 2020( Watchlist News: http://www.watchlistnews.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  Bank of America Corp DE 
Sells 61,004 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) September 16th, 2020 - Comments Off on Bank of 
America Corp DE Sells 61,004 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) - Filed Under[1] - by Lindsey 
Winhoffer[2]   Bank of America Corp DE cut its stake in shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 9.4% 
in the second quarter, according to the company in its most recent disclosure with the SEC. The firm owned 
591,394 shares of the transportation company's stock after selling 61,004 shares during the quarter. Bank of 
America Corp DE's holdings in Ryanair were worth $39,232,000 as of its most recent filing with the SEC.  A number 
of other hedge funds have also recently made changes to their positions in RYAAY. 
Janney Montgomery Scott LLC acquired a new position in shares of Ryanair during the 1st quarter worth about 
$261,000. Victory Capital Management Inc. acquired a new position in shares of Ryanair during the 1st quarter 
worth about $2,144,000. New York State Common Retirement Fund grew its position in shares of Ryanair by 
130.5% during the 1st quarter. New York State Common Retirement Fund now owns 72,236 shares of the 
transportation company's stock worth $3,835,000 after buying an additional 40,900 shares during the period. 
Oppenheimer Asset Management Inc. grew its position in shares of Ryanair by 37.0% during the 1st quarter. 
Oppenheimer Asset Management Inc. now owns 23,924 shares of the transportation company's stock worth 
$1,270,000 after buying an additional 6,464 shares during the period. Finally, CWM Advisors LLC grew its position 
in shares of Ryanair by 25.2% during the 1st quarter. CWM Advisors LLC now owns 10,817 shares of the 
transportation company's stock worth $574,000 after buying an additional 2,179 shares during the period. Hedge 
funds and other institutional investors own 44.15% of the company's stock.  NASDAQ RYAAY[3] opened at $85.83 
on Wednesday. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 52 week low of $44.44 and a 52 week high of $96.79. The stock has a 
market capitalization of $19.32 billion, a price-to-earnings ratio of 75.96 and a beta of 1.39. The company has a 
debt-to-equity ratio of 0.60, a quick ratio of 0.67 and a current ratio of 0.67. The stock's 50 day moving average 
price is $80.21 and its two-hundred day moving average price is $67.96.   Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last 
announced its quarterly earnings data on Monday, July 27th. The transportation company reported ($0.94) earnings 
per share (EPS) for the quarter, topping analysts' consensus estimates of ($1.15) by $0.21. Ryanair had a return on 
equity of 10.45% and a net margin of 3.61%. The company had revenue of $137.83 million for the quarter, 
compared to analysts' expectations of $138.60 million. On average, equities research analysts forecast that Ryanair 
Holdings plc will post -4.3 EPS for the current year. Several equities analysts recently issued reports on the 
company. Zacks Investment Research[4] upgraded Ryanair from a 'strong sell' rating to a 'buy' rating and set a 
Bank of America Corp DE Sells 61,004 Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY)
$68.00 price objective for the company in a research report on Tuesday, May 26th. Barclays reiterated an 
'overweight' rating on shares of Ryanair in a research report on Friday, August 14th. UBS Group reiterated a 'buy' 
rating on shares of Ryanair in a research report on Wednesday, May 20th. AlphaValue upgraded Ryanair to a 'sell' 
rating in a research report on Tuesday, September 8th. Finally, Liberum Capital lowered Ryanair from a 'buy' rating 
to a 'hold' rating in a research report on Monday. One analyst has rated the stock with a sell rating, six have given a 
hold rating and thirteen have issued a buy rating to the company's stock. The company presently has an average 
rating of 'Buy' and an average price target of $79.00. About Ryanair Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its 
subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the United Kingdom, and Other European 
countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled 
services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and merchandise; and marketing 
accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website. Recommended Story: What 
is the cash asset ratio?[5] Want to see what other hedge funds are holding RYAAY? Visit HoldingsChannel.com[6] 
to get the latest 13F filings and insider trades for Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY).Receive News &#38;

Eurowings takes over majority of Ryanair routes from Düsseldorf
Eurowings takes over majority of Ryanair routes from Düsseldorf
Airguide Business & AirguideBusiness.com
September 16, 2020
Copyright 2020 Pyramid Media Group Inc. All Rights Reserved
Section: Air and Travel Business News and Features; ISSN: 1939-666X
Length: 386 words
Body
Lufthansa's LCC steps in to offer flights from DUS to the vacation destinations in Greece, Portugal and Spain.
Lufthansa LCC subsidiary Eurowings is taking advantage of Ryanair's base closure at Düsseldorf International 
Airport (DUS) in Germany as it plans to take over up to 95% of the routes that have been operated by the Irish 
carrier.
The increased flight program should start on Oct. 24, the day when Ryanair wet-lease operator Laudamotion closes 
its base at DUS, which will see the loss of 150 crew jobs and seven Airbus A320 from the airport. Laudamotion co-
CEO Andreas Gruber previously told Aviation Week Network that the decision to close the DUS base was made by 
parent Ryanair, which is also closing its base at Stuttgart Airport (STR) on Sept. 30 affecting 70 jobs.
Eurowings CEO Jens Bischof said in a Sept. 15 statement that the closure of the Ryanair bases in Stuttgart and 
Düsseldorf was just the beginning. "With a closer look, the ultra-low-cost business model all over Germany is on its 
way to shrinking... Our clients don't search for tickets of (EURO)5 in times of a crisis, they are demanding an airline 
in which they can trust."
The number of Eurowings destinations from Düsseldorf-where the airline is headquartered-increases now to more 
than 80. The extended flying program includes services to Spanish vacation destinations Alicante (ALC), 
Fuerteventura (FUE), Gran Canaria (LPA), Ibiza (IBZ), Malaga (AGP), Palma de Mallorca (PMI) and Tenerife (TFS); 
Corfu (CFU), Heraklion (HER), Kos (KGS) and Rhodes (RHO) in Greece; and Faro (FAO) in Portugal.
Aviation Week Network understands that Eurowings has enough capacity available to handle the additional flight 
offering.
On Sept. 2 Eurowings said it would fly around 50 aircraft this autumn, but that will now likely be fewer as demand 
has weakened. From its current 90-strong fleet, the Lufthansa subsidiary has around 40 aircraft in long-term 
storage. "We have too many aircraft," Bischof said Sept. 2.

Eurowings takes over majority of Ryanair routes from Düsseldorf
Eurowings takes over majority of Ryanair routes from Düsseldorf
Airguide Business & AirguideBusiness.com
September 16, 2020
Copyright 2020 Pyramid Media Group Inc. All Rights Reserved
Section: Air and Travel Business Features; ISSN: 1939-666X
Length: 386 words
Body
Lufthansa's LCC steps in to offer flights from DUS to the vacation destinations in Greece, Portugal and Spain.
Lufthansa LCC subsidiary Eurowings is taking advantage of Ryanair's base closure at Düsseldorf International 
Airport (DUS) in Germany as it plans to take over up to 95% of the routes that have been operated by the Irish

its base at DUS, which will see the loss of 150 crew jobs and seven Airbus A320 from the airport. Laudamotion co-

parent Ryanair, which is also closing its base at Stuttgart Airport (STR) on Sept. 30 affecting 70 jobs.
Eurowings CEO Jens Bischof said in a Sept. 15 statement that the closure of the Ryanair bases in Stuttgart and 
Düsseldorf was just the beginning. "With a closer look, the ultra-low-cost business model all over Germany is on its 
way to shrinking... Our clients don't search for tickets of (EURO)5 in times of a crisis, they are demanding an airline 
in which they can trust."

than 80. The extended flying program includes services to Spanish vacation destinations Alicante (ALC),

Corfu (CFU), Heraklion (HER), Kos (KGS) and Rhodes (RHO) in Greece; and Faro (FAO) in Portugal.
Aviation Week Network understands that Eurowings has enough capacity available to handle the additional flight 
offering.
On Sept. 2 Eurowings said it would fly around 50 aircraft this autumn, but that will now likely be fewer as demand 
has weakened. From its current 90-strong fleet, the Lufthansa subsidiary has around 40 aircraft in long-term 
storage. "We have too many aircraft," Bischof said Sept. 2.

Goldman Sachs Group Inc. Decreases Stock Holdings in Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY)
Goldman Sachs Group Inc. Decreases Stock Holdings in Ryanair Holdings 
plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY)
American Banking and Market News
September 16, 2020 Wednesday
Copyright 2020 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 755 words
Body
Ryanair logo Goldman Sachs Group Inc. decreased its holdings in shares of  Ryanair Holdings plc 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 65.7% during the second quarter, according to its most recent filing with the Securities and 
Exchange Commission (SEC). The institutional investor  owned 130,389 shares of the transportation company's 
stock after selling 249,757 shares during the period. Goldman Sachs Group Inc. owned about 0.06% of Ryanair 
worth $8,650,000 as of its most recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC).  
Several other large investors have also made changes to their positions in the company. Massachusetts Financial 
Services Co. MA lifted its position in shares of  Ryanair by 3.8% during the 1st quarter. Massachusetts Financial 
Services Co. MA now owns 8,499,216 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $451,224,000 after 
buying an additional 308,003 shares in the last quarter.  Capital Research Global Investors lifted its holdings in  
Ryanair by 430.1% in the 1st quarter. Capital Research Global Investors now owns 3,766,971 shares of the 
transportation company's stock valued at $199,988,000 after purchasing an additional 3,056,407 shares in the last 
quarter.  Capital International Investors lifted its holdings in  Ryanair by 0.4% in the 1st quarter. Capital International 
Investors now owns 3,582,952 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $190,221,000 after 
purchasing an additional 15,500 shares in the last quarter.  Immersion Capital LLP lifted its holdings in  Ryanair by 
26.6% in the 1st quarter. Immersion Capital LLP now owns 2,182,341 shares of the transportation company's stock 
valued at $115,860,000 after purchasing an additional 458,047 shares in the last quarter.  Finally, Royal Bank of 
Canada lifted its holdings in  Ryanair by 22.9% in the 1st quarter. Royal Bank of Canada now owns 1,664,426 
shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $88,364,000 after purchasing an additional 310,399 shares 
in the last quarter. Hedge funds and other institutional investors own  44.15% of the company's stock.  
Shares of Ryanair stock  opened at $85.83 on Wednesday. The business has a 50-day moving average of $80.21 
and a 200 day moving average of $67.96. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 12 month low of $44.44 and a 12 month high 
of $96.79. The stock has a market capitalization of $19.32 billion, a price-to-earnings ratio of 75.96 and a beta of 
1.39. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.60, a current ratio of 0.67 and a quick ratio of 0.67.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last announced its earnings results on Monday, July 27th. The transportation company 
reported ($0.94) EPS for the quarter, beating analysts' consensus estimates of ($1.15) by $0.21. Ryanair had a 
return on equity of 10.45% and a net margin of 3.61%. The company had revenue of $137.83 million during the 
quarter, compared to analysts' expectations of $138.60 million.  Equities research analysts anticipate that  Ryanair 
Holdings plc will post -4.3 earnings per share for the current year.  
Goldman Sachs Group Inc. Decreases Stock Holdings in Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY)
A number of brokerages have weighed in on RYAAY. JPMorgan Chase & Co. upgraded Ryanair from a "neutral" 
rating to an "overweight" rating in a report on Monday, July 13th. Morgan Stanley  restated an "overweight" rating 
on shares of Ryanair in a report on Tuesday, July 28th. Liberum Capital downgraded Ryanair from a "buy" rating to 
a "hold" rating in a research note on Monday. Barclays  reaffirmed an "overweight" rating on shares of Ryanair in a 
research note on Friday, August 14th. Finally, Raymond James downgraded Ryanair from a "strong-buy" rating to 
an "outperform" rating and set a $90.00 target price for the company. in a research note on Friday, September 4th. 
One analyst  has rated the stock with a sell rating, six have issued  a hold rating and thirteen have given a buy 
rating to the company's stock. The company  has a consensus rating of "Buy" and an average target price of 
$79.00. 
Ryanair Company Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $88,364,000 after purchasing an additional 310,399 shares 
in the last quarter. Hedge funds and other institutional investors own  44.15% of the company's stock.

and a 200 day moving average of $67.96. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 12 month low of $44.44 and a 12 month high 
of $96.79. The stock has a market capitalization of $19.32 billion, a price-to-earnings ratio of 75.96 and a beta of 
1.39. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.60, a current ratio of 0.67 and a quick ratio of 0.67.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last announced its earnings results on Monday, July 27th. The transportation company 
reported ($0.94) EPS for the quarter, beating analysts' consensus estimates of ($1.15) by $0.21. Ryanair had a 
return on equity of 10.45% and a net margin of 3.61%. The company had revenue of $137.83 million during the 
quarter, compared to analysts' expectations of $138.60 million.  Equities research analysts anticipate that  Ryanair 
Holdings plc will post -4.3 earnings per share for the current year.  
Goldman Sachs Group Inc. Decreases Stock Holdings in Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY)
A number of brokerages have weighed in on RYAAY. JPMorgan Chase & Co. upgraded Ryanair from a "neutral" 
rating to an "overweight" rating in a report on Monday, July 13th. Morgan Stanley  restated an "overweight" rating 
on shares of Ryanair in a report on Tuesday, July 28th. Liberum Capital downgraded Ryanair from a "buy" rating to 
a "hold" rating in a research note on Monday. Barclays  reaffirmed an "overweight" rating on shares of Ryanair in a 
research note on Friday, August 14th. Finally, Raymond James downgraded Ryanair from a "strong-buy" rating to 
an "outperform" rating and set a $90.00 target price for the company. in a research note on Friday, September 4th. 
One analyst  has rated the stock with a sell rating, six have issued  a hold rating and thirteen have given a buy 
rating to the company's stock. The company  has a consensus rating of "Buy" and an average target price of 
$79.00. 
Ryanair Company Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

America Corp DE owned 0.26% of Ryanair worth $39,232,000 as of its most recent filing with the Securities and 
Exchange Commission.

company's stock.

Transavia France launches first domestic routes
Transavia France launches first domestic routes
Airguide Business & AirguideBusiness.com
September 16, 2020
Copyright 2020 Pyramid Media Group Inc. All Rights Reserved
Section: Air and Travel Business News and Features; ISSN: 1939-666X
Length: 509 words
Body
The LCC will begin domestic service in November, offering four routes form Nantes and one from Paris Orly.
A month after Air France-KLM Group secured the green light from pilots on plans for subsidiary Transavia France to 
fly domestic routes, the carrier has unveiled the first services it intends to operate.
Reservations are now open for five routes on departure from its bases at Paris Orly (ORY) and Nantes (NTE). 
Transavia's CCO Nicolas Hénin described the entry into the domestic market as "a new chapter in the company's 
development."
From Nov. 2, the low-cost unit will connect ORY with Biarritz (BIQ) 19X-weekly, in addition to Air France's services 
from Paris Charles de Gaulle (CDG).
Four routes from NTE will join Transavia's network, connecting the city in the Upper Brittany region with Marseille 
(MRS) 10X-weekly, Toulouse (TLS) 10X-weekly, Montpellier (MPL) 5X-weekly and Nice (NCE) 4X-weekly. All 
routes will be operated by Boeing 737-800NG, equipped with 189 seats.
TLS chairman Philippe Crébassa welcomed Transavia's entry to the NTE-TLS market, saying the lower cost flights 
would help to cater for rising levels of domestic demand in recent months as a consequence of the COVID-19 
pandemic.
The airline said it plans to announce further domestic routes "soon" as well as continuing the development of its 
medium-haul network from bases at ORY, NTE, Lyon (LYS) and MPL.
The launch of Transavia's inaugural domestic routes follows an agreement in August between Air France-KLM's 
management team and pilots' union SNPL, with the union backing an overhaul of Air France's domestic network.
"This network has been loss-making for several years despite continuous restructuring since 2000 and is subject to 
strong competition faced with the constant growth of low-cost airlines and the TGV high-speed train network," the 
airline group said at the time.
"This agreement permits Transavia to operate routes within France, and adjusts pilot guarantees pertaining to 
European network activity in line with the levels of activity expected on the domestic network over the coming 
years."
Transavia France launches first domestic routes
More than 90% of voting union members backed the domestic network restructure, with a turnout exceeding 82%. 
The agreement is the second with SNPL designed to facilitate the expansion of Transavia after a deal was reached 
last year to increase its French fleet beyond 40 aircraft.
According to data provided by OAG Schedules Analyser, Air France is currently the only operator of ORY-BIQ 
flights although easyJet serves BIQ from CDG.
Transavia will compete with Ryanair on NTE-MRS and with easyJet and Volotea on NTE-TLS and NTE-NCE. 
Volotea also serves NTE-MPL up to 2X-daily with easyJet set to begin the route in October.
AirGuide and Pyramid Media connects you to an affluent, influential group of business and leisure travelers from 
across

globe

and

and For Tech and Content Solutions.
Load-Date: December 29, 2020
End of Document

assigned a hold rating and thirteen have given a buy rating to the company. The average 1 year target price among

of several research reports.

lowered shares of Ryanair from a "buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a report on Monday. UBS Group reaffirmed a

Ireland May Impose Quarantine on Arrivals from Greece , Italy
Ireland May Impose Quarantine on Arrivals from Greece, Italy
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
September 16, 2020 Wednesday 2:18 AM EST
Copyright 2020 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 117 words
Body
 Ireland's new rules for travel may remove Greece and Italy from its COVID-19 green list, which exempts individuals 
from included countries from travel restrictions, Reuters reported Tuesday.
Irish budget airline Ryanair Holdings (RYA.L) condemned the update in a statement on Twitter saying it was "more 
delay and indecision from Micheál Martin's Government and NPHET."
The government agreed that inclusion in the green list will require a cumulative disease incidence rate of 25 or 
fewer cases per 100,000, based on the latest data from the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control.
Ryanair's stock was down nearly 1% on Tuesday's close.
Price (GBP): £12.02, Change: £-0.09, Percent Change: -0.78%
Load-Date: September 16, 2020
End of Document

European ADRs Climb Higher in Tuesday Trading
European ADRs Climb Higher in Tuesday Trading
MT Newswires Live Briefs
September 15, 2020 Tuesday 11:03 AM EST
Copyright 2020 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 229 words
Body
 American depositary receipts of European stocks were trading 1.18% higher at 923.69 on the BNY Mellon Europe 
Select ADR Index on Tuesday.
In continental Europe, the gainers were led by biopharmaceutical company ERYTECH Pharma (ERYP) and dating 
app operator Spark Networks (LOV), which climbed 9% and 7.2% respectively. They were followed by 
biopharmaceutical company Cellectis (CLLS) and furniture maker Natuzzi (NTZ), which rose 3.1% and 3%.
The decliners in continental Europe were led by biopharmaceutical company Biofrontera (BFRA) and internet 
advertising firm Criteo (CRTO), which fell 3.9% and 3.3% respectively. They were followed by Banco Bilbao 
Vizcaya Argentaria, (BBVA) and 3D printer maker Materialise (MTLS), which dropped 2.2% each.
In the UK and Ireland, the gainers were led by mining company Rio Tinto Group (RIO) and pharmaceutical 
company AstraZeneca PLC (AZN), which rose 3.3% and 2.6% respectively. They were followed by insurance firm 
Prudential (PUK) and biopharmaceutical company Bicycle Therapeutics plc (BCYC), which were up 2.3% and 
2.2%.
The decliners in the UK and Ireland were led by cruise line operator Carnival Corporation (CUK) and medical device 
maker EDAP (EDAP), which lost 7.7% and 3.1% respectively. They were followed by airplane lessor Fly Leasing 
Limited (FLY) and airline operator Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY), which were off 1.8% and 1.6%.
Load-Date: September 15, 2020
End of Document
Ryanair Anticipates No-Quarantine Travel System in EU
Ryanair Anticipates No-Quarantine Travel System in EU
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
September 15, 2020 Tuesday 1:26 AM EST
Copyright 2020 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 65 words
Body
 Ryanair (RYA.L) expects the European Commission to remove quarantine measures for traveling in Europe 
through the launch of a new system, Chief Executive Officer Eddie Wilson told Ireland's RTE radio Monday.
The new system is expected to be launched this week.
The airline's shares increased about 2% at the close of market on Monday.
Price (GBP): £12.11, Change: £0.21, Percent Change: +1.76%
Load-Date: September 15, 2020

Ryanair expects new EU travel system to put most of Europe on 'green list'
Ryanair expects new EU travel system to put most of Europe on 'green list'
Business World (Digest)
September 15, 2020 Tuesday
Copyright 2020 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: WORLD
Length: 117 words
Byline: Business World
Body
Ryanair expects the European Commission this week to unveil a new system of COVID-19 travel advice that will 
open up most regions of the continent to travel without quarantine, Chief Executive Eddie Wilson said on Monday.
The European Commission earlier this month proposed a common traffic light system for EU member states to 
coordinate border controls and remedy the current, confusing patchwork of coronavirus restrictions on travelers 
across Europe.
"I think you'll see the vast majority of Europe and UK returned into a green zone and then it'll be up to the individual 
health authorities to follow up on track and tracing them," Wilson told Ireland's RTE radio. (Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: October 5, 2020
End of Document

Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) Shares Sold by Great West Life Assurance Co. Can
Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Shares Sold by Great West Life 
Assurance Co. Can
American Banking and Market News
September 14, 2020 Monday
Copyright 2020 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 729 words
Body
Ryanair logo Great West Life Assurance Co. Can lowered its stake in  Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 
4.0% in the second quarter, according to the company in its most recent disclosure with the SEC. The institutional 
investor  owned 936,565 shares of the transportation company's stock after selling 38,543 shares during the 
quarter. Great West Life Assurance Co. Can owned about 0.42% of Ryanair worth $62,042,000 as of its most 
recent filing with the SEC.  
Several other hedge funds also recently bought and sold shares of RYAAY. Private Advisor Group LLC acquired a 
new position in shares of  Ryanair in the 2nd quarter worth approximately $25,000.  Rockefeller Capital 
Management L.P. boosted its stake in shares of  Ryanair by 239.7% during the 2nd quarter. Rockefeller Capital 
Management L.P. now owns 822 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $55,000 after buying an 
additional 580 shares during the last quarter.  PNC Financial Services Group Inc. boosted its stake in shares of  
Ryanair by 23.5% during the 2nd quarter. PNC Financial Services Group Inc. now owns 958 shares of the 
transportation company's stock worth $64,000 after buying an additional 182 shares during the last quarter.  Harbor 
Investment Advisory LLC acquired a new position in shares of  Ryanair during the 1st quarter worth about $91,000.  
Finally, Tower Research Capital LLC TRC acquired a new position in shares of  Ryanair during the 1st quarter 
worth about $124,000. Institutional investors and hedge funds own  44.15% of the company's stock.  
Several brokerages recently issued reports on RYAAY. Zacks Investment Research  upgraded shares of Ryanair 
from a "strong sell" rating to a "buy" rating and set a $68.00 target price for the company in a research note on 
Tuesday, May 26th. BidaskClub downgraded shares of Ryanair from a "buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a research 
note on Friday, August 21st. AlphaValue upgraded shares of Ryanair to a "sell" rating in a research note on 
Tuesday, September 8th. JPMorgan Chase & Co. upgraded shares of Ryanair from a "neutral" rating to an 
"overweight" rating in a research note on Monday, July 13th. Finally, Morgan Stanley  reiterated an "overweight" 
rating on shares of Ryanair in a research note on Tuesday, July 28th. One equities research analyst  has rated the 
stock with a sell rating, six have assigned  a hold rating and thirteen have given a buy rating to the company. The 
company  has an average rating of "Buy" and an average target price of $79.00. 
Shares of RYAAY stock  traded up $1.36 on Monday, hitting $85.74. 4,598 shares of the company's stock traded 
hands, compared to its average volume of 721,656. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.60, a quick ratio of 
0.67 and a current ratio of 0.67. Ryanair Holdings plc has a one year low of $44.44 and a one year high of $96.79. 
Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) Shares Sold by Great West Life Assurance Co. Can
The company's fifty day simple moving average is $79.30 and its 200 day simple moving average is $67.95. The 
stock has a market capitalization of $18.99 billion, a price-to-earnings ratio of 75.88 and a beta of 1.39.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last announced its quarterly earnings results on Monday, July 27th. The transportation 
company reported ($0.94) earnings per share for the quarter, beating the Thomson Reuters' consensus estimate of 
($1.15) by $0.21. The business had revenue of $137.83 million during the quarter, compared to analysts' 
expectations of $138.60 million. Ryanair had a net margin of 3.61% and a return on equity of 10.45%.  As a group, 
sell-side analysts anticipate that  Ryanair Holdings plc will post -4.3 earnings per share for the current fiscal year.  
About Ryanair
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

have assigned  a buy rating to the company. The stock currently has a consensus rating of "Buy" and a consensus 
price target of $79.00.

has a market capitalization of $18.99 billion, a P/E ratio of 74.67 and a beta of 1.39. The company has a debt-to-
equity ratio of 0.60, a current ratio of 0.67 and a quick ratio of 0.67.

Brave Warrior Advisors LLC Buys New Holdings in Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY)
Brave Warrior Advisors LLC Buys New Holdings in Ryanair Holdings plc 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY)
Newstex Blogs 
Week Herald
September 14, 2020 Monday 10:06 PM EST
Copyright 2020 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 764 words
Body
Sep 14, 2020( Week Herald: https://weekherald.com Delivered by Newstex)  Brave Warrior Advisors LLC bought a 
new stake in Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) in the second quarter, according to its most recent disclosure 
with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The fund bought 248,506 shares of the transportation company's 
stock, valued at approximately $16,486,000. Ryanair makes up approximately 0.8% of Brave Warrior Advisors 
LLC's holdings, making the stock its 15th largest holding. Brave Warrior Advisors LLC owned approximately 0.11% 
of Ryanair at the end of the most recent quarter. 
A number of other institutional investors have also recently modified their holdings of the stock. Private Advisor 
Group LLC acquired a new position in Ryanair during the 2nd quarter valued at about $25,000. Rockefeller Capital 
Management L.P. boosted its stake in Ryanair by 239.7% during the 2nd quarter. Rockefeller Capital Management 
L.P. now owns 822 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $55,000 after purchasing an additional 
580 shares during the last quarter. PNC Financial Services Group Inc. boosted its stake in shares of Ryanair by 
23.5% in the 2nd quarter. PNC Financial Services Group Inc. now owns 958 shares of the transportation company's 
stock worth $64,000 after buying an additional 182 shares during the last quarter. Harbor Investment Advisory LLC 
purchased a new position in shares of Ryanair in the 1st quarter worth approximately $91,000. Finally, Tower 
Research Capital LLC TRC purchased a new position in shares of Ryanair in the 1st quarter worth approximately 
$124,000. 44.15% of the stock is owned by institutional investors and hedge funds. RYAAY stock[1] traded up 
$2.59 during midday trading on Monday, reaching $86.97. 706,170 shares of the company's stock traded hands, 
compared to its average volume of 721,568. The company has a 50-day moving average price of $79.30 and a two-
hundred day moving average price of $67.95. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.60, a quick ratio of 0.67 
and a current ratio of 0.67. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 52 week low of $44.44 and a 52 week high of $96.79. The 
firm has a market capitalization of $18.99 billion, a PE ratio of 76.76 and a beta of 1.39. Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) 
last issued its earnings results on Monday, July 27th. The transportation company reported ($0.94) earnings per 
share (EPS) for the quarter, beating analysts' consensus estimates of ($1.15) by $0.21. Ryanair had a net margin of 
3.61% and a return on equity of 10.45%. The business had revenue of $137.83 million for the quarter, compared to 
analysts' expectations of $138.60 million. As a group, analysts predict that Ryanair Holdings plc will post -4.3 EPS 
for the current fiscal year. RYAAY has been the topic of a number of research analyst reports. Liberum Capital 
downgraded Ryanair from a "buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a research note on Monday. Raymond James 
downgraded Ryanair from a "strong-buy" rating to an "outperform" rating and set a $90.00 target price on the stock. 
in a research note on Friday, September 4th. AlphaValue upgraded Ryanair to a "sell" rating in a research note on 
Brave Warrior Advisors LLC Buys New Holdings in Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY)
Tuesday, September 8th. Barclays restated an "overweight" rating on shares of Ryanair in a research note on 
Friday, August 14th. Finally, JPMorgan Chase &#38; Co. upgraded Ryanair from a "neutral" rating to an 
"overweight" rating in a research note on Monday, July 13th. One equities research analyst has rated the stock with 
a sell rating, six have given a hold rating and thirteen have given a buy rating to the stock. Ryanair has a consensus 
rating of "Buy" and an average price target of $79.00.Ryanair ProfileRyanair Holdings plc, together with its 
subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the United Kingdom, and Other European 
countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled 
services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and merchandise; and marketing 
accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.Read More: Stock Selection -

Sunday Papers: Rishi Sunak urged to avert jobs crisis
Sunday Papers: Rishi Sunak urged to avert jobs crisis
Citywire
September 13, 2020 Sunday 6:10 AM GMT
Copyright 2020 Citywire Financial Publishers All Rights Reserved
Length: 433 words
Highlight: And Boris Johnson set to opt out of human rights laws to ease migrant deportation cases.
Body
Top stories
•
The Sunday Times: Rishi Sunak has been warned that he risks derailing the economy’s recovery if he 
does not stave off a jobs meltdown.
•
The Sunday Telegraph: Britain is preparing to opt out of major parts of European human rights laws, 
risking an explosive new row with the EU.
•
The Sunday Telegraph: The pound has endured its worst week since March as fractious Brexit trade talks 
with the EU threaten to collapse.
Business and economics
•
Mail on Sunday: Tough new restrictions to halt the spread of coronavirus may push unemployment to 
levels not seen since current records began almost 50 years ago, experts have warned.
•
The Sunday Telegraph: Ministers are ready to seize control of the railways after more than a quarter of a 
century of private ownership.
•
The Sunday Times: Tata Steel has crashed to a £654m loss and warned that its ability to continue as a 
going concern is at risk, underlining the steel industry’s dire finances.
•
Mail on Sunday: Ocado sales could exceed £2bn for the first time this year after customers flocked to order 
food from its new partner Marks & Spencer.
•
The Sunday Times: Imagination Technologies is to appoint a former BT chief executive, Peter Bonfield, to 
its board as it seeks to move on from a row over its Chinese owner.
•
The Daily Telegraph: Home working revolution signals the death of the coffee shop chain as falling 
commuter demand and overly ambitious growth plans pose existential questions for the industry.
•
Mail on Sunday: Controversial video app TikTok is poised to reach more than 8.5 million users in the UK 
this year despite growing fears about the Chinese-owned platform.
•
Mail on Sunday: Ryanair is braced for a pay rebellion this week over a €458,000 bonus for chief executive 
Michael O’Leary.
•
The Sunday Times: Games Workshop’s investors are being advised to vote against its chairman at the 
company’s annual meeting on Wednesday.
Sunday Papers: Rishi Sunak urged to avert jobs crisis
Share tips, comment and bids
•
Mail on Sunday (Midas share tips): BUY Genus.
•
Mail on Sunday (Midas share tips): BUY Associated British Foods.
•
The Sunday Times: SoftBank is set to sell ARM for more than £30bn to American tech giant Nvidia, as 
fears mount over the future of 3,000 domestic jobs at the Cambridge-based tech company.
•
The Sunday Times: Waitrose is in talks to buy an online meal-delivery start-up, Mindful Chef, as Sharon 
White looks to overhaul the John Lewis Partnership.
•
The Sunday Times: Online fashion retailer Boohoo is circling New Look as the struggling high-street chain 
teeters on the brink.
•
The Observer (Comment): Tax rises and austerity are not the way to shore up post-pandemic growth.

Sei Investments Co. Has $40.35 Million Stock Holdings in Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY)
Sei Investments Co. Has $40.35 Million Stock Holdings in Ryanair Holdings 
plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY)
American Banking and Market News
September 12, 2020 Saturday
Copyright 2020 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 761 words
Body
Ryanair logo Sei Investments Co. lessened its holdings in  Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) by 0.4% in the 
2nd quarter, according to the company in its most recent disclosure with the Securities & Exchange Commission. 
The firm owned 608,381 shares of the transportation company's stock after selling 2,471 shares during the period. 
Sei Investments Co. owned about 0.27% of Ryanair worth $40,351,000 as of its most recent SEC filing.  
Several other institutional investors have also modified their holdings of the company. CWM Advisors LLC boosted 
its stake in  Ryanair by 1.7% in the 2nd quarter. CWM Advisors LLC now owns 10,996 shares of the transportation 
company's stock worth $730,000 after purchasing an additional 179 shares during the period.  PNC Financial 
Services Group Inc. boosted its stake in shares of  Ryanair by 23.5% during the 2nd quarter. PNC Financial 
Services Group Inc. now owns 958 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $64,000 after buying an 
additional 182 shares during the last quarter.  Harbor Investment Advisory LLC boosted its stake in shares of  
Ryanair by 11.2% during the 2nd quarter. Harbor Investment Advisory LLC now owns 1,904 shares of the 
transportation company's stock worth $126,000 after buying an additional 191 shares during the last quarter.  
Private Advisor Group LLC acquired a new position in shares of  Ryanair during the 2nd quarter worth about 
$25,000.  Finally, Northwestern Mutual Investment Management Company LLC boosted its stake in shares of  
Ryanair by 3.7% during the 1st quarter. Northwestern Mutual Investment Management Company LLC now owns 
16,250 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $863,000 after buying an additional 579 shares during 
the last quarter. 44.15% of the stock is owned by institutional investors and hedge funds.  
Shares of RYAAY stock  traded down $0.92 on Friday, reaching $84.38. The stock had a trading volume of 524,926 
shares, compared to its average volume of 510,142. The company has a quick ratio of 0.67, a current ratio of 0.67 
and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.60. The firm has a market capitalization of $19.20 billion, a price-to-earnings ratio of 
74.67 and a beta of 1.39. The firm's 50-day moving average is $79.30 and its two-hundred day moving average is 
$67.95. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 12 month low of $44.44 and a 12 month high of $96.79.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last posted its quarterly earnings results on Monday, July 27th. The transportation 
company reported ($0.94) earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, topping the Thomson Reuters' consensus 
estimate of ($1.15) by $0.21. The business had revenue of $137.83 million for the quarter, compared to analyst 
estimates of $138.60 million. Ryanair had a net margin of 3.61% and a return on equity of 10.45%.  On average, 
sell-side analysts forecast that  Ryanair Holdings plc will post -4.3 earnings per share for the current fiscal year.  
Sei Investments Co. Has $40.35 Million Stock Holdings in Ryanair Holdings plc ( NASDAQ :RYAAY)
RYAAY has been the subject of a number of recent research reports. Credit Suisse Group  restated an "outperform" 
rating on shares of Ryanair in a research note on Tuesday, July 28th. UBS Group  restated a "buy" rating on shares 
of Ryanair in a research note on Wednesday, May 20th. BidaskClub downgraded shares of Ryanair from a "buy" 
rating to a "hold" rating in a research note on Friday, August 21st. AlphaValue raised shares of Ryanair to a "sell" 
rating in a report on Tuesday. Finally, Zacks Investment Research  raised shares of Ryanair from a "strong sell" 
rating to a "buy" rating and set a $68.00 target price on the stock in a report on Tuesday, May 26th. One analyst  
has rated the stock with a sell rating, five have issued  a hold rating and thirteen have given a buy rating to the 
stock. The stock presently has a consensus rating of "Buy" and a consensus target price of $79.00. 
Ryanair Company Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

How spending patterns changed UNDER LOCKDOWN
How spending patterns changed; UNDER LOCKDOWN
Financial Times (London, England)
September 12, 2020 Saturday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2020 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: MONEY;FEATURES; Pg. 6
Length: 271 words
Body
FT Money asked Starling Bank, one of the new digital challenger banks, for some insight on how our spending 
patterns have changed this year.
Not surprisingly, travel and transport were among the hardest hit areas of spending. Transport for London recorded 
a 95 per cent drop in spending during lockdown, although it has since bounced back to 60 per cent of pre-Covid 
levels.
However, the fear of using public transport has also boosted applications for car finance by nearly 25 per cent in 
July and August compared with a year previously, according to separate data last week.
Starling found transactions with airline Ryanair fell 95 per cent during lockdown, although spend has now recovered 
to almost 30 per cent of pre-March numbers. Airbnb was another casualty, with an 86 per cent drop in transactions 
during lockdown, which Starling said has only recovered by around 7 per cent since. However, food sales have 
soared. Spending at Tesco increased by 60 per cent during lockdown, while upmarket rival Waitrose was not far 
behind with an uptick of 42 per cent, both fuelled by increased demand for home delivery services.
Takeaways were popular too: Just Eat's transactions increased by 20 per cent during the past few months.
Internet shopping won hands down over the high street: Amazon spending jumped 82 per cent in lockdown, with 
average transaction values up 18 per cent.
How spending patterns changed UNDER LOCKDOWN
Anne Boden, chief executive and founder of Starling Bank, said the data indicated some "green shoots of recovery" 
in transport, travel and high street shopping. "We mustn't think we are out of the woods, but we are going in the 
right direction," she said.
Load-Date: September 13, 2020
End of Document
