European ADRs Move Higher in Friday Trading
European ADRs Move Higher in Friday Trading
MT Newswires Live Briefs
September 11, 2020 Friday 11:02 AM EST
Copyright 2020 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 225 words
Body
 American depositary receipts of European stocks were trading 1.17% higher at 911.10 on the BNY Mellon Europe 
Select ADR Index on Friday.
In continental Europe, the gainers were led by biopharmaceutical firm Biofrontera (BFRA) and 3D printer company 
voxeljet (VJET), which climbed 27% and 9.3% respectively. They were followed by biopharmaceutical companies 
argenx (ARGX) and DBV Technologies (DBVT), which rose 3.3% and 2.6%.
The decliners in continental Europe were led by biopharmaceutical company ERYTECH Pharma (ERYP) and bank 
Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria (BBVA), which fell 9.6% and 1.5% respectively. They were followed by internet 
browser company Opera Limited (OPRA) and brewing company Anheuser-Busch InBev (BUD), which were down 
1.4% and 1.3%.
In the UK and Ireland, the gainers were led by biopharmaceutical companies MorphoSys (MOR) and Mereo 
BioPharma Group (MREO), which rose 4.2% and 4.1% respectively. They were followed by mining company Rio 
Tinto Group (RIO) and biopharmaceutical company GW Pharmaceuticals (GWPH), which increased 4% and 3%.
The decliners in the UK and Ireland were led by airplane lessor Fly Leasing Limited (FLY) and biopharmaceutical 
company Amarin Corporation (AMRN), which fell  2% each. They were followed by airline operator Ryanair 
Holdings (RYAAY) and Trinity Biotech (TRIB), which were down 1.2% and 0.9%.
Load-Date: September 11, 2020
End of Document
Ryanair ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) Stock Rating Upgraded by AlphaValue
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Stock Rating Upgraded by AlphaValue
Newstex Blogs 
Transcript Daily
September 11, 2020 Friday 8:07 AM EST
Copyright 2020 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 699 words
Body
Sep 
11, 
2020( 
Transcript 
Daily: 
https://transcriptdaily.com 
Delivered 
by 
Newstex)  
https://www.marketbeat.com/logos/ryanair-holdings-plc-logo.jpgAlphaValue 
upgraded 
shares 
of 
Ryanair 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY) to a sell rating in a research report report published on Tuesday morning, The Fly[1] reports.A 
number of other equities analysts have also weighed in on RYAAY. Credit Suisse Group reiterated an outperform 
rating on shares of Ryanair in a research report on Tuesday, July 28th. 
BidaskClub lowered shares of Ryanair from a buy rating to a hold rating in a research report on Friday, August 21st. 
Morgan Stanley reiterated an overweight rating on shares of Ryanair in a research report on Tuesday, July 28th. 
UBS Group reissued a buy rating on shares of Ryanair in a report on Wednesday, May 20th. Finally, Raymond 
James downgraded Ryanair from a strong-buy rating to an outperform rating and set a $90.00 target price for the 
company. in a report on Friday, September 4th. One investment analyst has rated the stock with a sell rating, five 
have given a hold rating and thirteen have issued a buy rating to the stock. The stock currently has a consensus 
rating of Buy and an average price target of $79.00.Shares of RYAAY[2] opened at $85.30 on Tuesday. The 
company has a current ratio of 0.67, a quick ratio of 0.67 and a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.60. The firm has a market 
cap of $18.41 billion, a PE ratio of 75.49 and a beta of 1.39. The company's 50 day simple moving average is 
$79.04 and its 200-day simple moving average is $67.98. Ryanair has a 12-month low of $44.44 and a 12-month 
high of $96.79. Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last posted its quarterly earnings data on Monday, July 27th. The 
transportation company reported ($0.94) earnings per share for the quarter, beating analysts' consensus estimates 
of ($1.15) by $0.21. Ryanair had a net margin of 3.61% and a return on equity of 10.45%. The firm had revenue of 
$137.83 million for the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of $138.60 million. As a group, equities research 
analysts forecast that Ryanair will post -4.3 EPS for the current fiscal year. Several large investors have recently 
added to or reduced their stakes in RYAAY. Capital Research Global Investors raised its stake in shares of Ryanair 
by 430.1% during the 1st quarter. Capital Research Global Investors now owns 3,766,971 shares of the 
transportation company's stock worth $199,988,000 after buying an additional 3,056,407 shares during the last 
quarter. Polaris Capital Management LLC acquired a new position in shares of Ryanair during the 1st quarter worth 
$74,459,000. FMR LLC raised its stake in shares of Ryanair by 30.9% during the 2nd quarter. FMR LLC now owns 
5,276,515 shares of the transportation company's stock worth $350,045,000 after buying an additional 1,246,442 
shares during the last quarter. Baillie Gifford &#38; Co. raised its stake in shares of Ryanair by 10.8% during the 1st 
quarter. Baillie Gifford &#38; Co. now owns 7,530,081 shares of the transportation company's stock worth 
$399,771,000 after buying an additional 732,578 shares during the last quarter. Finally, Immersion Capital LLP 
raised its stake in shares of Ryanair by 26.6% during the 1st quarter. Immersion Capital LLP now owns 2,182,341 
Ryanair ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) Stock Rating Upgraded by AlphaValue
shares of the transportation company's stock worth $115,860,000 after buying an additional 458,047 shares during 
the last quarter. 44.15% of the stock is owned by institutional investors and hedge funds. About RyanairRyanair 
Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the United 
Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its

FTSE steady after positive week despite recovery, pound and Brexit doubts
FTSE steady after positive week despite recovery, pound and Brexit doubts
Citywire
September 11, 2020 Friday 10:26 AM GMT
Copyright 2020 Citywire Financial Publishers All Rights Reserved
Length: 673 words
Byline: Jeremy Gordon
Highlight: FTSE 100 hangs on to this week's gains after the US tech sell-off as investors digest mixed signals on 
UK's recovery, fresh travel restrictions and weak pound.
Body
UK markets were placid on Friday morning, hanging onto a week of solid gains, as traders digested the mixed 
signals from data on the economy’s recovery, a volatile pound and fresh travel retrictions. 
The UK’s economy expanded 6.6% in July as sectors like pubs and restaurants reopened, according to data from 
the Office for National Statistics. That was in line with expectations, but after a 20% contraction in the first quarter, 
output remained 11.7% below its pre-pandemic level in February.
‘While there was a marked bounce back in July, the economy is still languishing way below pre-pandemic levels 
with so many sectors of the economy suffering from a drop in demand,’ said Susannah Streeter, senior investment 
and markets analyst at Hargreaves Lansdown.
‘Consumer confidence has taken a battering and with the fresh tightening of social distancing rules once again, it’s 
likely to take another hit.
‘Already we have seen how newly imposed quarantine rules have affected the travel industry with British Airways’ 
owner IAG (IAG) and Easyjet (EZJ) announcing more flight cancellations this week due to a fall in bookings and 
Ryanair (RYA) calling the upcoming winter “a write off”.’
The FTSE 100 teetered around the 6,000 mark in early trading, before striking ahead 0.32%, up 20 points, to 6,022.
That came despite losses in US markets yesterday, with the S&P 500 retreating 1.76% after the Senate voted down 
a fresh economic relief package.
Sterling firmed 0.2% against the dollar and stabilised above the $1.28 mark at $1.283 but remained on course for a 
3% loss this week and its worst five-day performance since March.
The weakness in the pound has been caused by fears of a messy hard Brexit as the UK government announced 
plans to break international law by breaching the Brexit Withdrawal Agreement treaty signed with the EU in 
January. The European Commission threatened legal action yesterday, but Boris Johnson’s government has vowed 
to press ahead with debating the controversial legislation on Monday.
FTSE steady after positive week despite recovery, pound and Brexit doubts
‘This was the week when Brexit returned as a live issue for the markets. In the short-term the increased chances of 
a messy exit from the EU have been a tailwind for the UK’s flagship stock market index which looks on course for a 
positive week despite investors being challenged elsewhere by heavy selling on US markets,’ said AJ Bell 
investment director Russ Mould.
‘This is not a surprise, after all the FTSE 100 has international horizons and the resulting weakness in the pound 
has boosted the relative value of constituents’ overseas earnings.’
Over the week the blue-chip index has risen 3.9%, or 224 points, shaking off the tech-sell off in the US. The FTSE 
250 has gained 251 points, or 1.4%, over five days.
Among blue-chips, IAG was the biggest faller today, down 3.7% to 192.9p, after Portugal was added to the 
quarantine list yesterday.
Banks were also weak. Barclays (BARC) fell 1.8% to 103.2p, Lloyds (LLOY) by 1.7% to 26.0p and and Standard 
Chartered (STAN) 1.3% to 379.6p.
Burberry (BRBY) was the biggest gainer, up 2.9% to £15.38, with the market liking plans for the luxury retailer’s 
first issue of green bonds. 
Flutter Entertainment (FLTR) and Anglo American (AAL) were the next biggest gainers. The Betfair-owner rose 
2.2% to £117.65 while the mining firm ticked up 1.9% to £18.97.
Rio Tinto (RIO) also rose 1.5%, to £48.55, as chief executive Jean-Sébastien Jacques bowed to investor pressure 
to step down, drawing a line under a scandal over the destrution of ancient Aboriginal sites in Australia. 
The ‘mid-cap’ FTSE 250 index advanced 0.27%, or 47 points, to 17,621.
Royal Mail (RMG) lead the risers, jumping 7% to 236p, as investors continued to respond positively to this week’s 
trading update showing rapid growth in its parcels business during the pandemic.
Cineworld Group (CINE) led a rally in some beaten-up leisure stocks, advancing 6.1% to 52.6p.
B2B events and information business Ascential (ASCL) fell 5.3% to 294p while Wood Group (WG) retreated 3.7% 
to 221p as oil prices remained on the back foot.
Load-Date: September 22, 2020
End of Document
BA owner launches (EURO)2.75bn rights issue; Airlines IAG warns industry risks 'ruin' without support as it 
seeks emergency funds
BA owner launches (EURO)2.75bn rights issue; Airlines IAG warns industry 
risks 'ruin' without support as it seeks emergency funds
Financial Times (London, England)
September 11, 2020 Friday
Edition 1, USA Edition
Copyright 2020 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 8
Length: 519 words
Byline: PHILIP GEORGIADIS
Body
British Airways owner IAG has launched a steeply discounted (EURO)2.75bn rights issue to help shore up its 
finances through the disruption caused by coronavirus. The airline group also warned it expected to carry fewer 
passengers than forecast this year and next as travel restrictions and quarantine measures hamper its recovery.
Alex Cruz, BA chief executive, was one of several UK airline executives to write to the prime minister yesterday to 
plead for further support including testing on arrival. The letter, seen by the Financial Times, said the industry risked 
"ruin" otherwise.
IAG, which announced the emergency fundraising in July alongside a (EURO)2bn second-quarter loss, will issue 
nearly 3bn new shares at (EURO)0.92 each, a 36 per cent discount based on the new fully expanded share capital. 
Current shareholders will be entitled to buy three of the new shares for each two shares they currently own.
Stephen Furlong, analyst at Davy Research, said the discount was steeper than he had expected. The shareholder 
dilution was also more than he expected.
"You can see what they are trying to do, raise the money no matter what," he said. "The key was just to raise the 
money, the price was just a secondary thought."
BA owner launches (EURO)2.75bn rights issue; Airlines IAG warns industry risks 'ruin' without support as it 
seeks emergency funds
The rights issue won the overwhelming support of shareholders at IAG's annual meeting in Madrid this week. Qatar 
Airways, IAG's largest shareholder, which has steadily been building its stake in the airline group since 2015, took 
up its share entitlement in full.
IAG, which suffered a shareholder revolt over pay to top bosses including departed chief executive Willie Walsh, 
said it expected to be able to survive a "prolonged downturn" in air travel, and was confident it would emerge from 
the crisis as a more nimble and flexible company.
It has already cut more than 8,000 of its planned 13,000 jobs at BA, largely through voluntary redundancies.
The airline also said it had reached an agreement in principle over its restructuring at BA with union Unite, with a 
ballot of members set to follow in the coming weeks.
The company had total liquidity of (EURO)7.6bn by the end of August, including (EURO)5.8bn in cash and its 
equivalents.
The airline group is the latest major carrier to trim its flying schedules this week as expected passenger numbers 
fail to materialise, following easyJet, Ryanair and the US's United Airlines.
Bookings at IAG had levelled off since recovering to about 30 per cent of prepandemic levels by the end of June, it 
said in a trading update alongside the rights issue.
Short-haul bookings have fallen slightly since the UK and some other European countries introduced quarantine 
requirements on passengers returning from some popular tourist destinations including Spain, while long-haul travel 
remains subdued.
IAG now expects capacity to fall 63 per cent in 2020 compared with the previous year, as opposed to the 59 per 
cent previously forecast. For next year, it is expected to decline 27 per cent compared with 2019, as opposed to the 
24 per cent previously expected.
'The key was just to raise the money, the [discounted] price was just a secondary thought'
Load-Date: September 13, 2020
End of Document

seeks emergency funds

dilution was also more than he expected.
"You can see what they are trying to do, raise the money no matter what," he said. "The key was just to raise the 
money, the price was just a secondary thought."
BA owner launches (EURO)2.75bn rights issue Airlines IAG warns industry risks 'ruin' without support as it 
seeks emergency funds
The rights issue won the overwhelming support of shareholders at IAG's annual meeting in Madrid this week. Qatar 
Airways, IAG's largest shareholder, which has steadily been building its stake in the airline group since 2015, took 
up its share entitlement in full.
IAG, which suffered a shareholder revolt over pay to top bosses including departed chief executive Willie Walsh, 
said it expected to be able to survive a "prolonged downturn" in air travel, and was confident it would emerge from 
the crisis as a more nimble and flexible company.
It has already cut more than 8,000 of its planned 13,000 jobs at BA, largely through voluntary redundancies.
The airline also said it had reached an agreement in principle over its restructuring at BA with union Unite, with a 
ballot of members set to follow in the coming weeks.
The company had total liquidity of (EURO)7.6bn by the end of August, including (EURO)5.8bn in cash and its 
equivalents.
The airline group is the latest major carrier to trim its flying schedules this week as expected passenger numbers 
fail to materialise, following easyJet, Ryanair and the US's United Airlines.
Bookings at IAG had levelled off since recovering to about 30 per cent of prepandemic levels by the end of June, it 
said in a trading update alongside the rights issue.
Short-haul bookings have fallen slightly since the UK and some other European countries introduced quarantine 
requirements on passengers returning from some popular tourist destinations including Spain, while long-haul travel 
remains subdued.
IAG now expects capacity to fall 63 per cent in 2020 compared with the previous year, as opposed to the 59 per 
cent previously forecast. For next year, it is expected to decline 27 per cent compared with 2019, as opposed to the 
24 per cent previously expected.
'The key was just to raise the money, the [discounted] price was just a secondary thought'
Load-Date: September 13, 2020
End of Document
App and behaviour changing across smartphones during lockdown
App and behaviour changing across smartphones during lockdown
Newstex Blogs 
Coolsmartphone
September 11, 2020 Friday 2:00 PM EST
Copyright 2020 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 411 words
Byline: Zak Charmer
Body
Sep 11, 2020( Coolsmartphone: http://www.coolsmartphone.com Delivered by Newstex)  EE has announced their 
latest report into the changing habits and trends of their customers. It shows how the usage of services and apps 
has changed recently, as lockdown came in and then eased off. 
https://www.coolsmartphone.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/image015.jpg What's perhaps not too surprising, as 
the lockdown restrictions eased some weeks ago, was how traffic to travel and holiday websites more than doubled. 
EE saw sites like Airbnb, Booking.com, EasyJet, Ryanair and Skyscanner getting a big increase in usage and 
requests. This came as people fought to secure holidays and quick getaways in the sun. However, recent 
quarantine and restrictions on gatherings have meant that a lot of potential breaks are now either on hold or 
cancelled. 
https://www.coolsmartphone.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/andre-hunter-ndyfVMhl8qI-unsplash.jpg 
Likewise, being stuck inside, many online gaming sites like Mr Bet slots[1] have seen a big rise in usage. The 
enforced shut-in has meant that many are turning to digital distractions in greater numbers, with mobile gaming 
studios enjoying a big increase in profits and players enjoying the odd payout via sites like goto syndicate.casino[2]. 
The big increase in leisure time for more than 2bn smartphone owners has meant that gamers have found new 
games, new skills and now there's been a massive increase in mobile advertising revenue too. The massive mobile 
gaming revenues now put PC and console spending firmly in the shade, with smartphones earning developers 
$100bn this year. The advent of 'free to play' games, which allow free entry with in-game purchases earning a 
continual revenue stream for developers, has proved hugely successful with smartphone gamers. 
https://www.coolsmartphone.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/image021.jpg As we exit lockdown and enter a new 
period of restrictions, there's been an explosion of movement in-between. EE tracked smartphones and saw 
customers moving around the UK far more during the May bank holiday and June heatwaves. Previously there was 
a relatively strong adherence to the lockdown measures. Likewise, traffic to fitness apps such as Strava reduced 
massively during the lockdown. Instead - along with gaming - the network saw a big rise in streaming video usage 
on sites like YouTube, Netflix and Prime Video. [ 1]: https://mr.bet/casino/type/slot [ 2]: https://syndicate.casino

European ADRs Move Lower in Thursday Trading
European ADRs Move Lower in Thursday Trading
MT Newswires Live Briefs
September 10, 2020 Thursday 11:06 AM EST
Copyright 2020 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 221 words
Body
 American depositary receipts of European stocks were trading 0.42% lower at 911.70 on the BNY Mellon Europe 
Select ADR Index on Thursday.
In continental Europe, the gainers were led by internet browser company Opera Limited (OPRA) and 
biopharmaceutical company Cellectis (CLLS), which rose 3.2% and 2.5% respectively. They were followed by 
telecommunications company VEON Ltd. (VEON) and semiconductor company Sequans Communications (SQNS), 
which increased 2.4% and 2.3%.
The decliners in continental Europe were led by biopharmaceutical company ERYTECH Pharma (ERYP), which fell  
5.8%. Biopharmaceutical companies argenx  (ARGX) and Biofrontera (BFRA) each fell 2.6%.
In the UK and Ireland, the gainers were led by biopharmaceutical companies Adaptimmune Therapeutics (ADAP) 
and Akari Therapeutics (AKTX), which rose 3.9%  and 3.8% respectively. They were followed by biotech firm 
Autolus Therapeutics (AUTL) and airline operator Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY), which were up 3.3% each.
The decliners in the UK and Ireland were led by biopharmaceutical company Mereo BioPharma Group (MREO) and 
educational publisher Pearson (PSO), which fell 4%  and 3% respectively. They were followed by tobacco and 
consumer goods company British American Tobacco (BTI) and pharmaceutical firm Avadel Pharmaceuticals 
(AVDL), which lost 2.8% and 2.5%.

Ryanair in $1bn bond issue, $470mn share placement
Ryanair in $1bn bond issue, $470mn share placement
Airguide Business & AirguideBusiness.com
September 10, 2020
Copyright 2020 Pyramid Media Group Inc. All Rights Reserved
Section: Air and Travel Business News; ISSN: 1939-666X
Length: 358 words
Body
Ryanair (FR, Dublin Int'l) launched and sold an EUR850 million euro (USD1 billion) bond on September 7, which 
was more than five times oversubscribed, and also raised EUR400 million (USD470 million) in a share placement 
on September 3, shoring up the company's balance sheet. This was its first euro-bond sale since 2017, and the fact 
that investors put in EUR4.4 billion (USD5.2 billion) worth of orders for it was a sign that debt markets in Europe are 
starting to reopen to airlines, according to Reuters. It was the second bond issue by a European airline since the 
coronavirus pandemic wreaked havoc on passenger travel. 
As previously reported, Finnair (AY, Helsinki Vantaa) issued a hybrid bond on August 27. Ryanair's earlier share 
placement was via a "non-pre-emptive placing of new ordinary shares [...] in the capital of the company to 
institutional investors and certain others," the airline said in a stock exchange filing the day after the placing. A total 
of 35,242,291 new ordinary shares were placed, raising gross proceeds at just over the EUR400 million mark. 
These shares represent around 3.2% of the company's issued share capital before the placing. "Certain directors 
and members of the senior management team" also participated in the placement, buying 1,444,101 new shares at 
the placing price, Ryanair said in its statement. The airline said that the money raised was likely to "create 
opportunities for Ryanair to grow its network, and expand its fleet, to take advantage of lower airport and aircraft 
cost opportunities that are likely to arise." It added that the placing "is expected to help better position the group to 
move quickly to capitalise on such opportunities should they arise [and] should significantly de-risk the group's debt 
repayments over the next 12 months."

Ryanair logo Press coverage about Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) has trended very negative on Thursday, according 
to InfoTrie Sentiment. The research group rates the sentiment of news coverage by monitoring more than six 
thousand blog and news sources. The firm ranks coverage of public companies on a scale of negative five to 
positive five, with scores closest to five being the most favorable. Ryanair earned a news sentiment score of -3.80 
on their scale. InfoTrie also gave press coverage about the transportation company an news buzz score of 0 out of 
10, meaning that recent news coverage is extremely unlikely to have an impact on the company's share price in the 
near term.

rating in a research note on Monday, July 13th. Raymond James lowered shares of Ryanair from a "strong-buy" 
rating to an "outperform" rating and set a $90.00 target price for the company. in a research note on Friday,

on Friday, August 21st. One research analyst  has rated the stock with a sell rating, five have issued  a hold rating 
and thirteen have assigned  a buy rating to the company's stock. The stock currently has an average rating of "Buy" 
and an average price target of $79.00. 
Ryanair Company Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

The day in the markets
The day in the markets
Financial Times (London, England)
September 10, 2020 Thursday
Edition 1, European Edition
Copyright 2020 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 12
Length: 424 words
Body
What you need to know ? Rebound in tech stocks helps lift global equity markets higher ? Tourism-related stocks 
slide after Ryanair scales back passenger forecasts ? Brent crude bounces back from steep falls, climbing above 
$40 Global stocks bounced back yesterday, snapping a three-session rout in some of Wall Street's largest tech 
companies.
Tesla, the electric car company, was up more than 5 per cent at lunchtime, having plummeted by a fifth the day 
before.
The move higher followed a 4 per cent tumble in the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite on Tuesday, which was 
deemed a correction as defined by a 10 per cent decline from a recent peak.
In spite of the retreat, the Nasdaq is still up more than 20 per cent for the year and 60 per cent since its March lows.
Wall Street's major indices were all higher at lunchtime in New York with the S&P 500 up 2 per cent, the Nasdaq 
climbing 2.5 per cent and the Dow Jones Industrial Average 1.9 per cent higher.
Joe Little, chief strategist at HSBC Global Asset Management, said the resilient performance of equities and muted 
reaction in the bond market was a positive sign that the tech rout had not spread panic to other corners of the 
market.
The yield on US Treasuries, an asset often bought during times of market stress, barely moved, edging up 1 basis 
point to 0.70 per cent yesterday.
The day in the markets
The sell-off looked "similar to the phase in early June when we saw a little bit of ratcheting down and consolidation", 
Mr Little added. "The fact that we haven't seen a spillover into other asset classes is important."
European bourses also rebounded. The region-wide Stoxx Europe 600 closed up 1.6 per cent, despite stocks linked 
to tourism weighing on the benchmark.
Ryanair, Europe's largest low-cost airline, said it expected to carry fewer passengers than forecast in the 12 months 
to the end of March with the carrier warning that this winter would be "a write-off".
While shares in Ryanair rose after the statement, owing to "one of the strongest balance sheets in the industry", 
said Citi analysts, sector peers slid. Budget airline easyJet fell, as did travel group Tui and British Airways owner 
IAG.
The euro gained 0.3 per cent against the dollar to $1.1818 on a Bloomberg report that the European Central Bank's 
growth and inflation projections due today would only change slightly.
Oil prices clawed back some ground lost following steep falls on Tuesday that were triggered by fears that global 
demand for crude was waning.
Global benchmark Brent crude advanced 3.3 per cent to $41.08 a barrel. Ray Douglas
Load-Date: September 9, 2020
End of Document

The day in the markets What you need to know
The day in the markets; What you need to know
Financial Times (London, England)
September 10, 2020 Thursday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2020 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 16
Length: 778 words
Body
? Rebound in tech stocks helps lift global equity markets higher ? Tourism-related stocks slide after Ryanair scales 
back passenger forecasts ? Brent crude bounces back from steep falls, climbing above $40 Global stocks bounced 
back yesterday, snapping a three-session rout in some of Wall Street's largest tech companies.
Tesla, the electric car company, was up more than 5 per cent at lunchtime, having plummeted by a fifth the day 
before.
The move higher followed a 4 per cent tumble in the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite on Tuesday, which was 
deemed a correction as defined by a 10 per cent decline from a recent peak.
In spite of the retreat, the Nasdaq is still up more than 20 per cent for the year and 60 per cent since its March lows.
Wall Street's major indices were all higher at lunchtime in New York with the S&P 500 up 2 per cent, the Nasdaq 
climbing 2.5 per cent and the Dow Jones Industrial Average 1.9 per cent higher.
Joe Little, chief strategist at HSBC Global Asset Management, said the resilient performance of equities and muted 
reaction in the bond market was a positive sign that the tech rout had not spread panic to other corners of the 
market.
The yield on US Treasuries, an asset often bought during times of market stress, barely moved, edging up 1 basis 
point to 0.70 per cent yesterday.
The day in the markets What you need to know
The sell-off looked "similar to the phase in early June when we saw a little bit of ratcheting down and consolidation", 
Mr Little added. "The fact that we haven't seen a spillover into other asset classes is important."
European bourses also rebounded. The region-wide Stoxx Europe 600 closed up 1.6 per cent, despite stocks linked 
to tourism weighing on the benchmark.
Ryanair, Europe's largest low-cost airline, said it expected to carry fewer passengers than forecast in the 12 months 
to the end of March with the carrier warning that this winter would be "a write-off".
While shares in Ryanair rose after the statement, owing to "one of the strongest balance sheets in the industry", 
said Citi analysts, sector peers slid. Budget airline easyJet fell, as did travel group Tui and British Airways owner 
IAG.
The euro gained 0.3 per cent against the dollar to $1.1818 on a Bloomberg report that the European Central Bank's 
growth and inflation projections due today would only change slightly.
Oil prices clawed back some ground lost following steep falls on Tuesday that were triggered by fears that global 
demand for crude was waning.
Global benchmark Brent crude advanced 3.3 per cent to $41.08 a barrel. Ray Douglas
Tourism stocks slide after Ryanair warns of sluggish recovery Source: Refinitiv Indices rebased 97 96 98 99 100

Airlines cut flights after passengers fail to return
Airlines cut flights after passengers fail to return
Financial Times (London, England)
September 10, 2020 Thursday
Edition 1, USA Edition
Copyright 2020 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 6
Length: 365 words
Byline: CLAIRE BUSHEY; PHILIP GEORGIADIS
Body
US and European airlines warned yesterday of a grim outlook for the coming months, cutting back schedules as 
passengers continue to avoid air travel during the pandemic.
Ryanair, Europe's largest low-cost airline, reduced its forecast for passengers it expects to carry in the fiscal year to 
March, as the carrier warned that this winter would be "a write-off".
Finnair, Finland's flagship airline, said it would operate no more than 80 flights daily in October compared with the 
200 previously planned.
In the US, United Airlines said its capacity would fall 70 per cent compared with the third quarter of 2019. Earlier 
guidance was a fall of 65 per cent.
Revenue, too, will be lower than executives had forecast: down 85 per cent from the $11.4bn a year earlier, not 83 
per cent.
The cutbacks are part of a pattern in which airlines announce ambitious flying schedules only to trim them as 
departure dates approach and passengers fail to materialise. Industry body Iata said airlines globally were projected 
to lose a record $84bn this year.
Airlines cut flights after passengers fail to return
EasyJet cut its flight schedule earlier this week. Now Ryanair expects to carry 50m passengers in the 12 months to 
the end of March, down from the 60m projected in July. It had forecast more than 150m passengers before the 
pandemic.
Michael O'Leary, Ryanair chief executive, said the airline might cut more flights in the coming months.
The industry's recovery hopes have been hit hard by rising coronavirus cases across Europe and parts of the US. It 
is pushing for testing on arrival at airports to help cut quarantine times and encourage people back into the sky.
Airlines are also adapting to an environment where business travel has been hit particularly hard by focusing on 
leisure travel and customers flying to see friends and family.
United said it would launch seven new long-haul routes from the US over the next year: two from mainland cities to 
Hawaii, and five connecting diaspora populations to India and Africa.
"We're really focused on rethinking the network," said Patrick Quayle, United's vice-president of international 
network and alliances. "We're not just looking at adding everything back prior to the way it was before coronavirus."
Load-Date: September 9, 2020
End of Document
Airlines cut flights after passengers fail to return
Airlines cut flights after passengers fail to return
Financial Times (London, England)
September 10, 2020 Thursday
Edition 1, European Edition

Ryanair steels for winter 'write-off' as travel gloom deepens
Ryanair steels for winter 'write-off' as travel gloom deepens
Business World (Digest)
September 09, 2020 Wednesday
Copyright 2020 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: WORLD
Length: 520 words
Byline: Business World
Body
Ryanair slashed its annual passenger target by another 10 million on Wednesday, becoming the latest European 
airline to signal more capacity cuts as resurgent COVID-19 infections and travel restrictions dent recovery hopes.
"The winter of 2020 will be a write-off," Ryanair Group Chief Executive Michael O'Leary predicted in an interview. 
Europe's biggest low-cost carrier is preparing to close some bases and shrink others, he told Reuters.
Airlines have blamed an uneven patchwork of travel restrictions and quarantine rules across Europe for a stop-go 
recovery that has proven tougher than many expected.
Ryanair's low-cost rival easyJet, already cutting 4,500 jobs and closing three UK bases, further reduced its flying 
schedule for the current quarter on Tuesday.
And Wizz Air, which had touted an aggressive push for market share and even a new London Gatwick base, last 
week scaled down operations for the current quarter to 60% of capacity from the previously expected 80%.
Overall, September short-haul schedules have been cut to 43% of European capacity from 47.6% in August, 
Barclays analyst Rishika Savjani said - and that only tells part of the story.
"We think demand is tracking below these levels, and therefore we'd expect weaker load factors and weaker pricing 
for the quarter," Savjani said in a Tuesday note, referring to a key metric for the proportion of aircraft seats filled.
"Pricing is going to be aggressively down" in coming months, the Ryanair boss said. O'Leary was among the first 
CEOs to warn of a virus-induced price war in comments since borne out by a recovering Chinese market, where 
some carriers now offer all-you-can-fly deals.
Ryanair steels for winter 'write-off' as travel gloom deepens
Ryanair now expects to fly 50 million passengers in the fiscal year to March, one-third of the previous year's 
number. The goal was previously cut to 60 million in July from 80 million in May and could go lower still, O'Leary 
cautioned.
"We're probably looking at closing more bases and withdrawing more capacity in those countries where you're 
operating completely defective and non-scientific quarantines," he added - citing Britain, Ireland, Spain and 
Portugal.
Fourteen-day Western European infection rates that have risen to 64.9 per 100,000 from 19.4 in late July are "not 
reflected in share prices," with airline stocks up 14% over the period, Goodbody analyst Mark Simpson warned.
Behind the cutback announcements, Ryanair and Wizz remain relatively well positioned over traditional airlines with 
more "exposure to high-risk long-haul markets," Simpson said.
Further setbacks may leave legacy carriers like Air France-KLM and Lufthansa in need of yet more funding on top 
of their multibillion-euro state-backed bailouts, other analysts warn. Air France needs a strong recovery to avoid the 
looming prospect of nationalization.
O'Leary, who last week bolstered Ryanair's already strong balance sheet with a 400 million-euro share issue, 
remains confident the Irish no-frills carrier can come out on top.
"Our rivals have withdrawn huge amounts of capacity," he said. "The competitive landscape if anything is getting 
easier." (Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: September 30, 2020
End of Document
Ryanair steels for winter 'write-off' as travel gloom deepens
Ryanair steels for winter 'write-off' as travel gloom deepens
Airguide Business & AirguideBusiness.com
September 09, 2020
Copyright 2020 Pyramid Media Group Inc. All Rights Reserved
Section: Air and Travel Business Features; ISSN: 1939-666X
Length: 577 words
Body
Ryanair RYA.I slashed its annual passenger target by another 10 million on Wednesday, becoming the latest 
European airline to signal more capacity cuts as resurgent COVID-19 infections and travel restrictions dent 
recovery hopes.
"The winter of 2020 will be a write-off," Ryanair Group Chief Executive Michael O'Leary predicted in an interview. 
Europe's biggest low-cost carrier is preparing to close some bases and shrink others, he told Reuters.
Airlines have blamed an uneven patchwork of travel restrictions and quarantine rules across Europe for a stop-go 
recovery that has proven tougher than many expected.
Ryanair's low-cost rival easyJet EZJ.L, already cutting 4,500 jobs and closing three UK bases, further reduced its 
flying schedule for the current quarter on Tuesday.
And Wizz Air WIZZ.L, which had touted an aggressive push for market share and even a new London Gatwick 
base, last week scaled down operations for the current quarter to 60% of capacity from the previously expected 
80%.
Overall, September short-haul schedules have been cut to 43% of European capacity from 47.6% in August, 
Barclays analyst Rishika Savjani said - and that only tells part of the story.
"We think demand is tracking below these levels, and therefore we'd expect weaker load factors and weaker pricing 
for the quarter," Savjani said in a Tuesday note, referring to a key metric for the proportion of aircraft seats filled.
"Pricing is going to be aggressively down" in coming months, the Ryanair boss said. O'Leary was among the first 
CEOs to warn of a virus-induced price war in comments since borne out by a recovering Chinese market, where 
some carriers now offer all-you-can-fly deals.
Ryanair now expects to fly 50 million passengers in the fiscal year to March, one-third of the previous year's 
number. The goal was previously cut to 60 million in July from 80 million in May and could go lower still, O'Leary 
cautioned.
Ryanair steels for winter 'write-off' as travel gloom deepens
"We're probably looking at closing more bases and withdrawing more capacity in those countries where you're 
operating completely defective and non-scientific quarantines," he added - citing Britain, Ireland, Spain and 
Portugal.
Fourteen-day Western European infection rates that have risen to 64.9 per 100,000 from 19.4 in late July are "not 
reflected in share prices", with airline stocks up 14% over the period, Goodbody analyst Mark Simpson warned.
Behind the cutback announcements, Ryanair and Wizz remain relatively well positioned over traditional airlines with 
more "exposure to high-risk long-haul markets", Simpson said.
Further setbacks may leave legacy carriers like Air France-KLM AIR.PA and Lufthansa LHAG.DE in need of yet 
more funding on top of their multibillion-euro state-backed bailouts, other analysts warn. Air France needs a strong 
recovery to avoid the looming prospect of nationalisation.
O'Leary, who last week bolstered Ryanair's already strong balance sheet with a 400 million-euro share issue, 
remains confident the Irish no-frills carrier can come out on top.
"Our rivals have withdrawn huge amounts of capacity," he said. "The competitive landscape if anything is getting 
easier."

Ryanair lands (EURO)4.4bn worth of orders for 5-year bonds Fixed income
Ryanair lands (EURO)4.4bn worth of orders for 5-year bonds; Fixed income
Financial Times (London, England)
September 9, 2020 Wednesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2020 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 13
Length: 429 words
Byline: NIKOU ASGARI
Body
Ryanair has become the first big European airline to sell a bond since the start of the pandemic as investors 
shrugged off concerns about tightening travel restrictions in Europe.
The continent's largest low-cost carrier sold (EURO)850m of five-year bonds yesterday at a yield of 3 per cent after 
investors put in (EURO)4.4bn worth of orders. Airlines have been hit hard this year by nationwide shutdowns, travel 
restrictions and social distancing measures imposed by governments to reduce the spread of coronavirus. On 
Monday, the UK government added seven Greek islands to its quarantine list.
Mark Lynagh, co-head of Emea debt markets at BNP Paribas, who worked on the deal, said the bond sale was an 
"opportunistic refinancing exercise", as Ryanair has an (EURO)850m bond due to be paid back next summer.
The deal underlined the hunger for yield from investors after drastic action from central banks this year cut interest 
rates to record lows.
Ryanair's is the first straight bond sale by a European carrier in that environment, but follows an issuance by 
Finnair, which last month raised (EURO)200m of hybrid debt with a 10.25 per cent coupon in late August.
One UK-based fund manager and investor in Ryanair said the Irish airline had "the best-quality balance sheet" 
compared with European peers, with (EURO)3.9bn of cash at the end of June.
The investor added that a long-term decline in business travel did not present a threat to the group.
Ryanair lands (EURO)4.4bn worth of orders for 5-year bonds Fixed income
The carrier has maintained its triple B, investment grade credit rating during the pandemic, unlike rivals such as 
British Airways, which sank further into junk territory yesterday after Moody's downgraded its owner IAG to Ba2. 
The rating agency cited IAG's high exposure to long-haul and corporate travel.
Yesterday's bond sale by Ryanair followed a (EURO)400m raising of equity last week.
"In an environment where it's all about liquidity, they are in a very solid position," said a banker working on the bond 
deal.
Ryanair declined to comment. The airline came under fire this month for paying a (EURO)450,000 bonus to chief 
executive Michael O'Leary despite putting staff on furlough and taking £600m in government aid.
A resurgence of virus cases has led Ryanair to cut flight numbers for autumn. It had hoped to run 70 per cent of its 
normal schedule in September.
"They'll always do well in a recession," said Mr Lynagh, noting that Ryanair had lots of domestic routes that would 
be unaffected by restrictions on international travel.
Rival British Airways sank further into junk territory after Moody's downgraded parent IAG to Ba2
Load-Date: September 8, 2020
End of Document
Ryanair lands (EURO)4.4bn worth of orders for 5-year bonds Fixed income
Ryanair lands (EURO)4.4bn worth of orders for 5-year bonds; Fixed income
Financial Times (London, England)
September 9, 2020 Wednesday
Edition 1, USA Edition
Copyright 2020 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS; Pg. 12
Length: 429 words
Byline: NIKOU ASGARI
Body
Ryanair has become the first big European airline to sell a bond since the start of the pandemic as investors 
shrugged off concerns about tightening travel restrictions in Europe.
The continent's largest low-cost carrier sold (EURO)850m of five-year bonds yesterday at a yield of 3 per cent after 
investors put in (EURO)4.4bn worth of orders. Airlines have been hit hard this year by nationwide shutdowns, travel 
restrictions and social distancing measures imposed by governments to reduce the spread of coronavirus. On 
Monday, the UK government added seven Greek islands to its quarantine list.
Mark Lynagh, co-head of Emea debt markets at BNP Paribas, who worked on the deal, said the bond sale was an 
"opportunistic refinancing exercise", as Ryanair has an (EURO)850m bond due to be paid back next summer.
The deal underlined the hunger for yield from investors after drastic action from central banks this year cut interest 
rates to record lows.
Ryanair's is the first straight bond sale by a European carrier in that environment, but follows an issuance by 
Finnair, which last month raised (EURO)200m of hybrid debt with a 10.25 per cent coupon in late August.
One UK-based fund manager and investor in Ryanair said the Irish airline had "the best-quality balance sheet" 
compared with European peers, with (EURO)3.9bn of cash at the end of June.
The investor added that a long-term decline in business travel did not present a threat to the group.
Ryanair lands (EURO)4.4bn worth of orders for 5-year bonds Fixed income
The carrier has maintained its triple B, investment grade credit rating during the pandemic, unlike rivals such as 
British Airways, which sank further into junk territory yesterday after Moody's downgraded its owner IAG to Ba2. 
The rating agency cited IAG's high exposure to long-haul and corporate travel.
Yesterday's bond sale by Ryanair followed a (EURO)400m raising of equity last week.
"In an environment where it's all about liquidity, they are in a very solid position," said a banker working on the bond 
deal.
Ryanair declined to comment. The airline came under fire this month for paying a (EURO)450,000 bonus to chief 
executive Michael O'Leary despite putting staff on furlough and taking £600m in government aid.
A resurgence of virus cases has led Ryanair to cut flight numbers for autumn. It had hoped to run 70 per cent of its 
normal schedule in September.
"They'll always do well in a recession," said Mr Lynagh, noting that Ryanair had lots of domestic routes that would 
be unaffected by restrictions on international travel.
Rival British Airways sank further into junk territory after Moody's downgraded parent IAG to Ba2
Load-Date: September 8, 2020
End of Document

Critical Survey: Ryanair ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) & LATAM Airlines Group ( NASDAQ :LTMAQ)
Critical Survey: Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) & LATAM Airlines Group 
(NASDAQ:LTMAQ)
Newstex Blogs 
Transcript Daily
September 9, 2020 Wednesday 8:06 AM EST
Copyright 2020 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 656 words
Body
Sep 09, 2020( Transcript Daily: https://transcriptdaily.com Delivered by Newstex)  Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY[1]) 
and LATAM Airlines Group (OTCMKTS:LTMAQ[2]) are both transportation companies, but which is the superior 
stock? We will contrast the two businesses based on the strength of their institutional ownership, earnings, 
profitability, risk, analyst recommendations, valuation and dividends. Valuation &#38; Earnings This table compares 
Ryanair and LATAM Airlines Group's top-line revenue, earnings per share (EPS) and valuation. 
Ryanair has higher earnings, but lower revenue than LATAM Airlines Group. LATAM Airlines Group is trading at a 
lower price-to-earnings ratio than Ryanair, indicating that it is currently the more affordable of the two stocks. Insider 
and Institutional Ownership44.2% of Ryanair shares are held by institutional investors. Comparatively, 0.1% of 
LATAM Airlines Group shares are held by institutional investors. 7.8% of LATAM Airlines Group shares are held by 
company insiders. Strong institutional ownership is an indication that endowments, hedge funds and large money 
managers believe a company will outperform the market over the long term.ProfitabilityThis table compares Ryanair 
and LATAM Airlines Group's net margins, return on equity and return on assets. Analyst RecommendationsThis is a 
summary of recent ratings and price targets for Ryanair and LATAM Airlines Group, as provided by MarketBeat.  
Ryanair currently has a consensus price target of $90.00, indicating a potential upside of 10.01%. Given Ryanair's 
higher possible upside, analysts plainly believe Ryanair is more favorable than LATAM Airlines Group. 
SummaryRyanair beats LATAM Airlines Group on 10 of the 12 factors compared between the two stocks.Ryanair 
Company ProfileRyanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services 
in Ireland, the United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of 
various ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of 
beverages, food, and merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel 
insurance through its Website. In addition, it sells bus and rail tickets onboard its aircraft and through its Website, as 
well as gift vouchers through its Website; and markets car parking, attractions, and activities through its Website. As 
of June 30, 2018, the company operated a fleet of 440 Boeing 737 aircraft; and offered approximately 2,000 
scheduled short-haul flights per day serving approximately 200 airports in Europe. Ryanair Holdings plc was 
founded in 1985 and is headquartered in Swords, Ireland.LATAM Airlines Group Company ProfileLATAM Airlines 
Group S.A., together with its subsidiaries, provides passenger and cargo air transportation services in Peru, 
Argentina, the United States, Europe, Colombia, Brazil, Ecuador, Chile, the Asia Pacific, and rest of Latin America. 
The company provides passenger transport services to approximately 145 destinations in 26 countries, as well as 
cargo services to approximately 151 destinations in 29 countries; and operates loyalty programs. As of December 
Critical Survey: Ryanair ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) & LATAM Airlines Group ( NASDAQ :LTMAQ)
31, 2019, it operated a fleet of 331 aircraft, which include 320 passenger aircraft and 11 cargo aircraft; and 
subleased 11 aircraft comprising 10 passenger aircraft and 1 cargo aircraft to third parties. The company was 
formerly known as LAN Airlines S.A. and changed its name to LATAM Airlines Group S.A. in June 2012. LATAM 
Airlines Group S.A. was founded in 1929 and is headquartered in Santiago, Chile. On May 26, 2020, LATAM 
Airlines Group S.A., along with its affiliates, filed a voluntary petition for reorganization under Chapter 11 in the U.S. 
Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York. [ 1]: https://www.marketbeat.com/stocks/NASDAQ/RYAAY/ 
[ 2]: https://www.marketbeat.com/stocks/OTCMKTS/LTMAQ/

Ryanair accesses unsecured Eurobond markets again with 850m issue
Ryanair accesses unsecured Eurobond markets again with 850m issue
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
September 9, 2020 Wednesday 11:30 AM GMT
Copyright 2020 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 215 words
Highlight: Irish budget airline Ryanair announced that it has issued an 850m Eurobond at a fixed 2.875% for five 
years.
Body
It is the first bond in three years for Ryanair and the second by a European airline since the Covid-19 pandemic, 
reported Reuters. Last month, Finland flag carrier Finnair issued new euro-denominated in aggregate (EURO)200m 
capital securities. 
The bond will be listed on the Irish Stock Exchange (Euronext) and offer access to both Europe and the rest of the 
world. Barclays, BNP Paribas and Citigroup served as the joint bookrunners. Ryanair Group CFO Neil Sorahan 
said: "We are pleased to have accessed the unsecured Eurobond markets again. "This (EURO)850m transaction, 
which follows Ryanair's successful (EURO)400m share placing last week, was multiple times oversubscribed and 
was keenly priced at a coupon of 2.875%." The move came a week after Ryanair raised gross proceeds of nearly 
(EURO)400m through a non-pre-emptive placing of new ordinary shares as part of the company's strategy for 
greater financial flexibility to capitalise on significant post-Covid-19 growth opportunities. In a separate 
development, Ryanair has launched a 50% off over 750,000 seats for travel in September and October to various 
destinations across Europe, North Africa and the Middle East. In May, China Southern Airlines reportedly planned 
to issue up to CNY16bn ($2.25bn) in A-share convertible bonds.
Load-Date: September 16, 2020
End of Document
Wings clipped British Airways owner IAG suffers shareholder opposition to pay awards
Wings clipped British Airways owner IAG suffers shareholder opposition to 
pay awards
Financial Times (London, England)
September 9, 2020 Wednesday
Edition 1, European Edition
Copyright 2020 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 5
Length: 403 words
Byline: PHILIP GEORGIADIS
Body
British Airways owner IAG suffered a significant shareholder revolt yesterday over plans to pay outgoing chief 
executive Willie Walsh and other executives large bonuses even as it struggles through the worst crisis in its 
history.
A fifth of voting shareholders voted against IAG's remuneration report, which includes a bonus of £883,000 for Mr 
Walsh for his work in 2019, as part of a total package worth just under £3.2m.
Influential shareholder advisory group ISS had urged investors to vote against the packages at the group's annual 
meeting. IAG executives have since taken pay cuts as part of a costcutting drive.
IAG said it was "disappointed" that just over 20 per cent of shareholders voted against the pay award.
"Aviation has been decimated by the impact of the pandemic, resulting in substantial losses for the global industry. 
It is the worst crisis we have ever faced," Mr Walsh told shareholders on his final day as chief executive. Mr Walsh 
handed over to Luis Gallego yesterday, a company insider who ran Spanish flag carrier Iberia for almost seven 
years.
The Spaniard will have to chart a course through an uncertain winter as Covid-19 cases rise and the company 
downsizes itself to reflect the impact of the pandemic. IAG is also in the process of renegotiating its (EURO)1bn 
deal to buy Air Europa, which it expects to go through in the next six months.
Wings clipped British Airways owner IAG suffers shareholder opposition to pay awards
Investors overwhelmingly backed IAG's (EURO)2.75bn rights issue, helping it to shore up its balance sheet as the 
outlook for the industry remains uncertain.
Mark Simpson, an aviation analyst at Goodbody, said the new shareholder funding still left IAG "stretched", while 
rating agency Moody's downgraded the airline's debt just hours before Mr Walsh's swansong as it warned of 
liquidity concerns if there was no meaningful passenger recovery.
Mr Walsh told shareholders not to expect a rapid increase in flights over the coming months, and called on 
governments to introduce Covid-19 testing regimes and to expand travel corridors.
The former pilot, who earned the nickname "slasher Walsh" for his tough stance in two decades of labour 
negotiations, closed his career at IAG under fire from several sides.
But Mr Walsh has won respect from within the industry for his modernisation drive at IAG. Michael O'Leary, chief 
executive of Ryanair, said that Mr Walsh had been "head and shoulders the best airline CEO in the world over the 
past 10 years".
See Markets
Graphic
 
Investors are bridling at plans to pay large bonuses to outgoing chief Willie Walsh and other executives - Jason 
Alden
Load-Date: September 8, 2020

Market Chatter: Ryanair Reportedly Trims Annual Passenger Target to 50 Million from 60 Million Previously
Market Chatter: Ryanair Reportedly Trims Annual Passenger Target to 50 
Million from 60 Million Previously
MT Newswires Live Briefs
September 9, 2020 Wednesday 9:21 AM EST
Copyright 2020 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 191 words
Body
 Ryanair (RYAAY) has trimmed its annual passenger target by another 10 million amid increasing COVID-19 
infections and travel restrictions, Reuters reported Wednesday, citing the major European airline's chief executive.
The Irish no-frills carrier now expects to fly 50 million passengers in the fiscal year to March, the news agency 
reported, citing Michael O'Leary as saying in an interview. The goal was previously slashed to 60 million in July 
from 80 million in May, said O'Leary, who also warned that pricing is going to be aggressively down in the coming 
months.
Ryanair is getting ready to close some bases and shrink others as "the winter of 2020 will be a write-off," Reuters 
reported, quoting O'Leary.
Western European 14-day infections rates have recently risen to 64.9 per 100,000, from 19.4 in late July, according 
to the report.
Shares fell more than 2.5% in pre-bell trading.
(Market Chatter news is derived from conversations with market professionals globally. This information is believed 
to be from reliable sources but may include rumor and speculation. Accuracy is not guaranteed.)
Price: 79.79, Change: -2.02, Percent Change: -2.47
Load-Date: September 9, 2020
End of Document
Ryanair Trims FY21 Passenger Target On Hindered Demand Amid COVID-19
Ryanair Trims FY21 Passenger Target On Hindered Demand Amid COVID-19
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
September 9, 2020 Wednesday 6:36 AM EST
Copyright 2020 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 136 words
Body
 Ryanair (RYA.L) further reduced its fiscal 2021 passenger target to 50 million from 60 million as the COVID-19 
pandemic continues to pummel demand, Reuters reported Wednesday, citing Chief Executive Michael O'Leary.
O'Leary said that if the lockdown restrictions and the slump in demand continue, the passenger numbers could drop 
even further with airlines consequently reducing fares to boost demand, according to the report.
Subsequently, the carrier could close a number of its bases and cut capacity in countries such as the UK, Ireland, 
Spain and Portugal, while increasing capacity in Germany and Italy.
O'Leary added that Ryanair is expected to carry out less than 3,000 redundancies, the report said.
The company's shares fell about 2% on Wednesday morning.
Price (GBP): £11.34, Change: £11.34, Percent Change: -2.45%
Load-Date: September 9, 2020
End of Document
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Upgraded to 'Sell' at AlphaValue
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) Upgraded to 'Sell' at AlphaValue
Newstex Blogs 
Zolmax.com
September 9, 2020 Wednesday 7:06 AM EST
Copyright 2020 Newstex LLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 670 words
Body
Sep 
09, 
2020( 
Zolmax.com: 
http://www.zolmax.com/ 
Delivered 
by 
Newstex)  
https://www.marketbeat.com/logos/ryanair-holdings-plc-logo.jpgAlphaValue 
upgraded 
shares 
of 
Ryanair 
(NASDAQ:RYAAY) to a sell rating in a report issued on Tuesday morning, The Fly[1] reports.Several other equities 
analysts have also commented on RYAAY. JPMorgan Chase &#38; Co. 
raised shares of Ryanair from a neutral rating to an overweight rating in a research report on Monday, July 13th. 
Zacks Investment Research[2] raised shares of Ryanair from a strong sell rating to a buy rating and set a $68.00 
price objective for the company in a research report on Tuesday, May 26th. Credit Suisse Group reissued an 
outperform rating on shares of Ryanair in a research report on Tuesday, July 28th. Barclays reissued an overweight 
rating on shares of Ryanair in a research report on Friday, August 14th. Finally, BidaskClub lowered shares of

ratio of 0.60, a quick ratio of 0.67 and a current ratio of 0.67. The company's 50-day simple moving average is 
$78.62 and its 200-day simple moving average is $68.06. Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last released its quarterly

on equity of 10.45%. The business had revenue of $137.83 million for the quarter, compared to analysts'

current year. A number of institutional investors and hedge funds have recently made changes to their positions in

market[2]COVID-19 Outbreak- Inflight Advertising Market Overview:Today advertisements can be seen everywhere 
such as on the seats of grocery carts, on the walls of an airport walkway, on the sides of buses, heard in telephone 
hold messages and also on the fuselage of an aircraft or on-board. Inflight advertising recently becomes a 
significant source of revenues for airlines all over the world. Inspired by ground public transport, air carriers have 
started to explore a great potential of on-board marketing and advertising. Inflight advertising provides smarter and 
cost-effective way of communicating with the customer and it is one of the new methods to inform potential 
customers about products and services and how to obtain and use them.COVID-19 Outbreak- Inflight Advertising

The FTSE is higher as we head into early afternoon trade with Sterling still loitering around that six week low and 
news from drug giantAstraZenecaPLC (LON:AZN) that it is putting its coronavirus vaccine trials on hold after a 
patient participating got poorly which has triggered fears of finding a solution to coronavirus restrictions. Speaking of 
which, the UK government has said gatherings will be slashed from 30 people to 6 after the rise in coronavirus 
cases. 
This news is impacting hospitality stocks including JD Wetherspoon (LON:JDW). Sterling is still being beaten by 
concerns over a break down of Brexit deal talks between Britain and the EU and Boris Johnson's rhetoric going into 
the talks has been quite tough.Ryanair (LON:RYA) has cut its target for passenger numbers this year by another 10 
million, to 50 million and predicted a price war to encourage passengers to fly.Among the small caps is Amryt 
Pharma (NASDAQ:AMYT) (LON:AMYT) which has posted positive results from its skin gel phase III success for 
skin gel to treat people with a rare and chronic skin disease - there is an interview with the CEO Joe Wiley on our 
website now. Argo Blockchain (LON:ARB) has reported a surge in earnings and revenues in its first half - with a 
surge of Bitcoins mined of over 500% from the previous year. And Inspired Energy (LON:INSE) has revealed 
revenue in the half-year to June by 25% to 20.9mln.

AlphaValue Upgrades Ryanair ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) to "Sell"
AlphaValue Upgrades Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) to "Sell"
American Banking and Market News
September 8, 2020 Tuesday
Copyright 2020 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 653 words
Body
Ryanair logo Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) was upgraded by research analysts at AlphaValue to a "sell" rating in a 
report released on Tuesday, The Fly  reports. 
Other equities analysts have also issued research reports about the company. Barclays  reissued an "overweight" 
rating on shares of Ryanair in a research note on Friday, August 14th. Credit Suisse Group  reissued an 
"outperform" rating on shares of Ryanair in a research report on Tuesday, July 28th. UBS Group  restated a "buy" 
rating on shares of Ryanair in a research report on Wednesday, May 20th. Zacks Investment Research  raised 
shares of Ryanair from a "strong sell" rating to a "buy" rating and set a $68.00 target price on the stock in a 
research note on Tuesday, May 26th. Finally, BidaskClub cut shares of Ryanair from a "buy" rating to a "hold" rating 
in a research note on Friday, August 21st. One analyst  has rated the stock with a sell rating, five have issued  a 
hold rating and thirteen have given a buy rating to the stock. The company currently has a consensus rating of 
"Buy" and an average target price of $79.00. 
Ryanair stock  opened at $83.21 on Tuesday. The stock has a market capitalization of $18.73 billion, a PE ratio of 
73.64 and a beta of 1.39. The business has a 50 day simple moving average of $78.38 and a 200-day simple 
moving average of $68.10. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.60, a current ratio of 0.67 and a quick ratio 
of 0.67. Ryanair has a 12 month low of $44.44 and a 12 month high of $96.79.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last posted its quarterly earnings data on Monday, July 27th. The transportation 
company reported ($0.94) EPS for the quarter, topping the Thomson Reuters' consensus estimate of ($1.15) by 
$0.21. Ryanair had a return on equity of 10.45% and a net margin of 3.61%. The company had revenue of $137.83 
million during the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of $138.60 million.  On average, equities research 
analysts anticipate that  Ryanair will post -4.3 EPS for the current fiscal year.  
Large investors have recently added to or reduced their stakes in the business. Sumitomo Mitsui Trust Holdings Inc. 
raised its stake in shares of  Ryanair by 178.6% in the second quarter. Sumitomo Mitsui Trust Holdings Inc. now 
owns 52,627 shares of the transportation company's stock valued at $3,491,000 after acquiring an additional 
33,738 shares in the last quarter.  Harbor Investment Advisory LLC increased its holdings in  Ryanair by 11.2% 
during the 2nd quarter. Harbor Investment Advisory LLC now owns 1,904 shares of the transportation company's 
stock worth $126,000 after purchasing an additional 191 shares during the period.  Virtu Financial LLC acquired a 
new stake in  Ryanair in the 2nd quarter valued at about $582,000.  State Street Corp raised its position in  Ryanair 
by 21.9% in the 1st quarter. State Street Corp now owns 88,058 shares of the transportation company's stock 
valued at $4,675,000 after purchasing an additional 15,821 shares in the last quarter.  Finally, Natixis Advisors L.P. 
AlphaValue Upgrades Ryanair ( NASDAQ :RYAAY) to "Sell"
boosted its stake in shares of  Ryanair by 3.7% in the 2nd quarter. Natixis Advisors L.P. now owns 123,751 shares 
of the transportation company's stock valued at $8,210,000 after buying an additional 4,362 shares during the 
period. Institutional investors own  44.15% of the company's stock.  
Ryanair Company Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

About Ryanair
Ryanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services in Ireland, the 
United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary 
services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of beverages, food, and 
merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel insurance through its Website.

Ryanair logo Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) was upgraded by stock analysts at AlphaValue to a "sell" rating in a 
research note issued on Tuesday, The Fly  reports.

Airline Stocks - Top Airline Stocks to Buy Now 
A number of other equities analysts have also issued reports on the company. BidaskClub lowered Ryanair from a 
"buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a report on Friday, August 21st. Barclays  reissued an "overweight" rating on shares 
of Ryanair in a report on Friday, August 14th. Zacks Investment Research  raised Ryanair from a "strong sell" rating 
to a "buy" rating and set a $68.00 price target on the stock in a report on Tuesday, May 26th. UBS Group  reissued 
a "buy" rating on shares of Ryanair in a report on Wednesday, May 20th. Finally, JPMorgan Chase & Co. upgraded 
shares of Ryanair from a "neutral" rating to an "overweight" rating in a research report on Monday, July 13th. One 
equities research analyst  has rated the stock with a sell rating, five have issued  a hold rating and thirteen have 
given a buy rating to the company's stock. Ryanair presently has an average rating of "Buy" and a consensus target 
price of $79.00. 
Shares of RYAAY stock  opened at $83.21 on Tuesday. The stock's 50-day moving average is $78.38 and its two-
hundred day moving average is $68.10. The firm has a market cap of $18.73 billion, a price-to-earnings ratio of 
73.64 and a beta of 1.39. Ryanair has a 1 year low of $44.44 and a 1 year high of $96.79. The company has a 
debt-to-equity ratio of 0.60, a quick ratio of 0.67 and a current ratio of 0.67.  
Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY) last issued its quarterly earnings data on Monday, July 27th. The transportation 
company reported ($0.94) earnings per share (EPS) for the quarter, topping the consensus estimate of ($1.15) by 
$0.21. The company had revenue of $137.83 million for the quarter, compared to analyst estimates of $138.60 
million. Ryanair had a return on equity of 10.45% and a net margin of 3.61%.  As a group, research analysts predict 
that  Ryanair will post -4.3 EPS for the current year.

Mile-high bonus club Airline boards [...]
Mile-high bonus club Airline boards [...]
Financial Times (London, England)
September 8, 2020 Tuesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2020 The Financial Times Limited All Rights Reserved
Section: FEATURES; Pg. 14
Length: 386 words
Byline: Cat Rutter Pooley
Body
Mile-high bonus club Airline boards have their heads firmly in the clouds, judging from recent recommendations 
from investor advisory group Institutional Shareholder Services.
Wizz Air, International Airlines Group and now Ryanair have attracted ISS's ire over bonuses for bosses in recent 
months. Despite considerable turbulence in the industry, boards at each group have still decided their chief 
executives deserve their bonuses.
Willie Walsh walks away with £883,000, half of it cash, for his final full-year stint in charge of IAG - more than his 
salary. Michael O'Leary pockets 92 per cent of the maximum he could have been awarded at Ryanair, 
(EURO)458,000 in cash. Wizz chief executive József Váradi got a discretionary bonus of (EURO)533,000 in shares, 
despite missing the profit targets that are meant to be the sole determinant of the company's incentive plan.
All have taken advantage of cheap loans from the government's CCFF. All have announced job cuts. Both Ryanair 
and IAG are tapping shareholders for cash too.
Each group has an explanation for why the payouts are more grounded than they appear. The bonuses are for 
financial years that were all but over before Covid came along in the case of Ryanair and Wizz, whose fiscal years 
end in March. Mr Walsh's relates to an even earlier era, the year to December 2019, and the decision to pay it 
made in early March.
Mile-high bonus club Airline boards [...]
The chief executives have taken pay pain along with employees, Mr O'Leary shrinking his salary to a quarter of the 
2019 financial year sum. Mr Váradi had piloted Wizz Air with considerable aplomb before the crisis. He would have 
hit profit targets had the airline not suffered fuel hedge losses linked to Covid-19, something outside his control.
ISS recognises the rationalisations, and reckons payouts miss the mark nonetheless. It is right to recommend 
investors vote against the pay reports. The airline industry is going through an exceptional patch, and executives 
should expect to take an exceptional hit to their pay.
What will be enlightening is how boards react if they lose the nonbinding vote, as Wizz already has. Ryanair only 
scraped through last year; this year's annual meeting takes place next week. Failure to engage with investors' 
concerns will show that boards have still not come fully down to earth.
cat.rutterpooley@ft.com
Load-Date: September 7, 2020
End of Document

S&P Holds Ryanair at BBB Despite Passenger Traffic Slump; Outlook Negative
S&P Holds Ryanair at BBB Despite Passenger Traffic Slump; Outlook 
Negative
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
September 8, 2020 Tuesday 00:09
Copyright 2020 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 97 words
Body
 S&P Global Ratings on Monday maintained Ryanair Holdings' (RYA.L) BBB ratings and removed them from 
CreditWatch Negative, even as the COVID-19 pandemic dented the airline's passenger traffic.
The outlook is negative, reflecting the expectation that Ryanair's financial metrics would still be under 
"considerable" pressure in the next few quarters.
S&P said it expects Ryanair to post a substantial operating cash flow deficit in the fiscal year ending March 31, 
2021, as it anticipates a 60% to 70% plunge in traffic in 2020.
Price (GBP): £11.85, Change: £-0.22, Percent Change: -1.86%

Lauda Europe completes Maltese certification
Lauda Europe completes Maltese certification
Airguide Business & AirguideBusiness.com
September 07, 2020
Copyright 2020 Pyramid Media Group Inc. All Rights Reserved
Section: Air and Travel Business News; ISSN: 1939-666X
Length: 229 words
Body
Lauda Europe (Malta Int'l) has received its Air Operator's Certificate (AOC) from Transport Malta, the Director 
General of the authority, Charles Pace, said on September 5. The official register of airlines certified in Malta has 
yet to reflect the event. The new Maltese subsidiary of Ryanair Holdings, which is due to replace Austria-based 
Lauda (OE, Vienna) by the beginning of the Winter 2020/21 season, has already taken delivery of three A320-200s 
transferred from its predecessor, now registered as 9H-LMG (msn 4603), 9H-LMH (msn 5015), and 9H-LMP (msn 
3616). All three Airbus remain parked at Vienna for the time being. Lauda Europe is due to take over all thirty A320-
200s from Lauda, which will be closed once the transfer is completed. The Irish parent said that Maltese labour 
laws allow its subsidiary to operate more flexibly across the whole of Europe in comparison to Austrian rules. Lauda 
Europe will exclusively operate as a capacity provider for Ryanair (FR, Dublin Int'l) and will not fly under its own 
code.

Sep 06, 2020( DailyPolitical: http://www.dailypolitical.com/ Delivered by Newstex)  LATAM Airlines Group 
(OTCMKTS:LTMAQ[1]) and Ryanair (NASDAQ:RYAAY[2]) are both transportation companies, but which is the 
superior stock? We will contrast the two companies based on the strength of their profitability, analyst 
recommendations, earnings, dividends, risk, institutional ownership and valuation. ProfitabilityThis table compares 
LATAM Airlines Group and Ryanair's net margins, return on equity and return on assets. 
Valuation &#38; Earnings This table compares LATAM Airlines Group and Ryanair's revenue, earnings per share 
(EPS) and valuation. Ryanair has lower revenue, but higher earnings than LATAM Airlines Group. LATAM Airlines 
Group is trading at a lower price-to-earnings ratio than Ryanair, indicating that it is currently the more affordable of 
the two stocks. Insider and Institutional Ownership0.1% of LATAM Airlines Group shares are owned by institutional 
investors. Comparatively, 44.2% of Ryanair shares are owned by institutional investors. 7.8% of LATAM Airlines 
Group shares are owned by insiders. Strong institutional ownership is an indication that large money managers, 
endowments and hedge funds believe a company will outperform the market over the long term.Analyst 
RecommendationsThis is a breakdown of recent recommendations for LATAM Airlines Group and Ryanair, as 
reported by MarketBeat.com.  Ryanair has a consensus price target of $90.00, indicating a potential upside of 
8.16%. Given Ryanair's higher probable upside, analysts clearly believe Ryanair is more favorable than LATAM 
Airlines Group. SummaryRyanair beats LATAM Airlines Group on 10 of the 12 factors compared between the two 
stocks.LATAM Airlines Group Company ProfileLATAM Airlines Group S.A., together with its subsidiaries, provides 
passenger and cargo air transportation services in Peru, Argentina, the United States, Europe, Colombia, Brazil, 
Ecuador, Chile, the Asia Pacific, and rest of Latin America. The company provides passenger transport services to 
approximately 145 destinations in 26 countries, as well as cargo services to approximately 151 destinations in 29 
countries; and operates loyalty programs. As of December 31, 2019, it operated a fleet of 331 aircraft, which include 
320 passenger aircraft and 11 cargo aircraft; and subleased 11 aircraft comprising 10 passenger aircraft and 1 
cargo aircraft to third parties. The company was formerly known as LAN Airlines S.A. and changed its name to 
LATAM Airlines Group S.A. in June 2012. LATAM Airlines Group S.A. was founded in 1929 and is headquartered in 
Santiago, Chile. On May 26, 2020, LATAM Airlines Group S.A., along with its affiliates, filed a voluntary petition for 
reorganization under Chapter 11 in the U.S. Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York.Ryanair 
Company ProfileRyanair Holdings plc, together with its subsidiaries, provides scheduled-passenger airline services 
in Ireland, the United Kingdom, and Other European countries. The company is also involved in the provision of 
various ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled services and Internet-related services; in-flight sale of 
LATAM Airlines Group (OTCMKTS:LTMAQ) and Ryanair (OTCMKTS:RYAAY) Head-To-Head Analysis
beverages, food, and merchandise; and marketing accommodation services, holidays, car hire, and travel 
insurance through its Website. In addition, it sells bus and rail tickets onboard its aircraft and through its Website, as 
well as gift vouchers through its Website; and markets car parking, attractions, and activities through its Website. As 
of June 30, 2018, the company operated a fleet of 440 Boeing 737 aircraft; and offered approximately 2,000 
scheduled short-haul flights per day serving approximately 200 airports in Europe. Ryanair Holdings plc was

company is also involved in the provision of various ancillary services, such as non-flight scheduled services and

Market Chatter: Proxy Adviser Slams Ryanair CEO's Annual Bonus Package Amid COVID-19
Market Chatter: Proxy Adviser Slams Ryanair CEO's Annual Bonus Package 
Amid COVID-19
Live Briefs PRO Global Markets
September 7, 2020 Monday 00:22
Copyright 2020 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 172 words
Body
 Proxy adviser Institutional Shareholder Services criticized Ryanair Holdings (RYA.L) Chief Executive Michael 
O'Leary's proposed 458,000-euro ($542,114) annual bonus during the COVID-19 pandemic, London's Financial 
Times reported Friday.
The move comes after ISS scrutinized International Consolidated Airlines Group (IAG.L) CEO Willie Walsh's 
sending-off payment of 883,000 pounds sterling ($1.2 million).
British pilots' union BALPA also called the CEO bonuses an insult to staff redundancies or taking pay cuts, the 
report said.
Ryanair's bonus plan is scheduled to be voted on Sept. 17, while IAG's vote is expected to take place Tuesday, the 
report added.
Ryanair rose about 4%, while the British Airways parent increased about 2% at the close of market on Friday.
(Market Chatter news is derived from conversations with market professionals globally. This information is believed 
to be from reliable sources but may include rumor and speculation. Accuracy is not guaranteed.)
Price (GBP): £12.07, Change: £0.41, Percent Change: +3.56%
Load-Date: September 7, 2020
End of Document
